story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSinger with&nbspindie rockers&nbspCornershop&nbspfights leaving the EU for professional – and intensely personal – reasonsClick to followIndy PoliticsTjinder Singh says Cornershop were 'anti-Brexit even before Brexit was here'For Tjinder Singh, the lead singer of indie rockers&nbspCornershop, the fight for a Final Say referendum on the outcome of the Brexit drama is both professional – and intensely personal.The musician is co-ordinating a protest by more than 60 industry colleagues warning the damage from leaving the EU – to everything from touring and sales, to copyright legislation and collection of royalties – will be huge.But Mr Singh has also been “consumed by Brexit” since the referendum result, both because his wife is French and because he sees dangerous echoes of his childhood in Wolverhampton.How to march with The Independent for a Final Say on BrexitIndeed, the 50-year-old is so determined to secure a fresh public vote that he is preparing for his second anti-Brexit march this month – having also attended the silly-but-serious “Wooferendum” demonstration.First the professional. It is universally acknowledged that British music is one of this country’s biggest success stories, with UK artists releasing a staggering one&nbspin 8 albums bought anywhere in the world.For musicians – the protestors include Jarvis Cocker and members of The Chemical Brothers, Super Furry Animals, Mogwai and Pink Floyd, among others – “being in the EU” has played a major part.They point out that no less than 60 per cent of revenues paid to the UK come from the EU, fuelled by a free sharing of data which is now under threat, and that the astonishing vinyl revival is at risk from higher import fees.But, for musicians, it’s much bigger than that. Music is and must be “about embracing and respecting other cultures”, they say – while Brexit will, inevitably, see Britain “isolate ourselves”.“Our concern is that new musicians won’t have the privileges that we had,” says Mr Singh, whose catchy number-one single “Brimful of Asha” was a key soundtrack of the&nbsplate 1990s.Older musicians have grim memories of needing special permission to “get into countries when there wasn’t free movement, but that was a long time ago”, he says.He explains: “Britain is used as a base for touring France and Germany, but artists need to be able to get equipment and people over to Europe and the fear is that will stop because it will be too expensive.”But, for Mr Singh, leaving the EU goes so much deeper than his love for music, because his opposition is an ethos, a state of mind. “Cornershop were anti-Brexit even before Brexit was here,” he says.Created with Sketch.People's Vote march – demanding vote on final Brexit deal Show all years of cuts – which means they will feel betrayed.“These people won’t be satisfied by what happens after Brexit, because there will be yet more cuts to services, the country will be hobbled by Brexit,” he warns.Here he also targets Jeremy Corbyn for “failing to provide leadership by opposing Brexit”, while echoing claims that EU immigration has lowered workers’ wages here.“Corbyn has gone down the same line and said a lot of the rot that the Conservatives put out – and even Ukip,” Mr Singh protests.“Coming out of the EU is not what’s best for workers and workers’ rights. title: theresa may brexit transition period eu meeting brussels negotiations latest
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSuggestion likely to enrage BrexiteersClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May has confirmed that she is considering asking the EU for an extended Brexit transition period in a bid to break the deadlock in talks.The Prime Minister is understood to have raised the possibility of a longer period in meetings with EU leaders yesterday, but Downing Street was previously tight-lipped about the exchanges – which are likely to enrage Tory eurosceptics.Arriving at the second day of the European Council summit in Brussels Ms May told reporters that the option had emerged to extend the controversial period, but that it would only be for “a matter of months”.EU leaders decide to shelve plans for Brexit summit in NovemberThe period – during which the UK would stay completely tied to EU rules without any say on them – is hugely unpopular with Brexiteers, who believe it would make Britain a “vassal state” of the bloc.On Wednesday evening European Parliament president Antonio Tajani&nbsptold reporters the Prime Minister had “mentioned the idea of an extension of a transition period as one possibility that is on the table and would be looked into” in a meeting with him and the 27 EU leaders.Other Brussels sources confirmed to The Independent that the PM had also raised the policy in bilateral meetings with top EU officials, and that British negotiators had been sounding out the possibility of extending it in negotiations for “months”.The transition period as currently negotiated would begin when Britain leaves the EU on 29 March 2019 and continue until the first day of 2021. During it practically&nbspnothing would change for the UK – Britain would continue to implement all EU law, stay in the single market and customs union and under the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.&nbspThe UK would however not be represented in EU institutions like the Parliament, Council, and Commission and would therefore have no say in drawing up the rules.“A further idea that has emerged – and it is an idea at this stage – is to create an option to extend the implementation period for a matter of months – and it would only be for a matter of months,” the Prime Minister told reporters on the summit’s doorstep.“But the point is that this is not expected to be used, because we are working to ensure that we have that future relationship in place by the end of December 2020.“I’m clear that it is possible to do that and that is what we are working for, and in those circumstances there would be no need for any proposal of this sort and I’m clear that I expect the implementation period to end at the end of December 2020.”Most trade experts and people in Brussels agree the current 21-month period will realistically not be enough time to negotiate a full free trade agreement between the UK and EU, and that an extension is inevitable. If the transition expires before a new trade deal was ready the UK would yet again face the prospect of a no-deal.&nbspOne senior UK government official, speaking in the margins of the summit, said: “If you were literally jotting the I’s and crossing the Ts on the future relationship you could extend the implementation period while you complete the negotiation process.Created with Sketch.Brexit so far: in pictures Show all 31Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Boris Johnson MP, Labour MP Gisela Stuart and UKIP MP Douglas Carswell address the people of Stafford in Market Square during the Vote Leave Brexit Battle Bus tour on 17 May 2016. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis: The prime minister&nbspis stuck with an unpopular policy done on the cheap by her predecessors, says Benjamin&nbspKentish. But she cannot let it distract her from securing a deal on BrexitClick to followIndy PoliticsThe row over universal credit could not have come at a worse time for&nbspTheresa May. With most of Whitehall’s resources and almost all of Downing Street’s political capital focused on Brexit, No 10 is now also having to stave off growing backbench unrest about the government’s flagship welfare policy.The introduction of the new system has been dogged by delays and warnings about the impact on struggling families. Ministers have already made a series of changes and no one doubts that more will be needed. Esther McVey, the work and pensions secretary, told the Commons yesterday that the government “will make sure we get this benefit right”. People may ask why, six years after the change was approved by parliament, it has not done so already.Tory backbenchers are increasingly concerned about the policy and the impact it will have on their constituents. This is not a minor reform – the switch to universal credit will affect eight million working-age people. MPs are already being bombarded with tales of people forced into debt, destitution and, according to one Labour MP, prostitution&nbspas they are transferred to the new system.Labour fails to force government to release universal credit papersPolitically, too, the fiasco is damaging for the Conservatives. If the next election is not until 2022, it is issues of public services and welfare that could prove pivotal, especially universal credit, which directly affects more than one in eight voters. The public bought into the idea of belt-tightening when it was needed to reduce the deficit. With the economy growing and Ms May having heralded the end of austerity, that argument no longer holds.The tales of hardship that accompany every debate on universal credit will trouble Tories who fear once again being seen as the nasty party, and fuel perceptions that Conservative modernisers worked so hard to dispel.The disastrous implementation of the policy also spectacularly undermines what will inevitably be one of the Tories’ main electoral arguments: that they are the party of competence and efficient management. Universal credit was introduced long before she became prime minister. It is hard to believe that, if she could, Ms May would not quietly scrap it and be done. Wednesday that food prices were the main downward pull on prices.There was also downward pressure from clothing and transport.Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and fuel prices, declined Archer of the EY Item Club.“This is likely to be the consequence of a higher oil price, previously announced rises in domestic energy prices and recent sterling weakness.”According to the ONS, factory gate prices rose to 3.1 per cent in September, up from 2.9 per cent in August, while industrial input prices were up 10.3 per cent.Separately, it&nbspreported that annual UK house price inflation in August eased to 3.2 per cent, down from 3.4 per cent in July.The ONS reported on Tuesday that average wages, excluding bonuses, were up 3.1 per cent in August, the highest in almost a title: uk retail sales latest september heatwave consumer gdp
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSales volumes declined by 0.8 per cent in the month, worse than the 0.4 per cent anticipated by City of London analystsClick to followThe IndependentThere was no growth from non-food store sales in SeptemberThere was a bigger than expected fall in UK retail sales in September, official figures showed on Thursday.The Office for National Statistics reported that sales volumes declined by 0.8 per cent in the month, worse than the 0.4 per cent anticipated by City of London analysts.What is really going wrong with the UK retail sector?This followed strong activity from shoppers in the July and August heatwave, when Britons splashed out on food and drink.In September food sales were down sharply. There was a decline in non-store retailing activity and no growth from non-food stores.Over the three months to September sales volumes were still up 1.2 per cent, although this was down from the 1.9 per cent rate in the three months to July.Retail sales account for around 30 per cent of total consumer spending and are seen as a bellwether of the direction of the overall economy.“Some easing back in retail sales was always to be expected in September given the overall strength in August and July,” said&nbspHoward Archer of the EY Item Club.He added that third-quarter growth “buoys belief that consumer spending&nbspmade an appreciable contribution as GDP growth likely improved to at least 0.6 per cent&nbspquarter-on-quarter in the third quarter.”The ONS estimates that GDP growth was 0.4 per cent in the second quarter of 2018.But other analysts were less optimistic.“It looks like consumer spending – along with the weather – peaked in early summer and has been declining ever since,” said Ben Brettell of Hargreaves Lansdown.“Where we go from here is highly uncertain. Brexit is hitting consumer confidence hard, but on the plus side wage growth has hit a decade high while inflation is falling. So consumers look likely to have more spending power – the issue is whether they choose to use it, or keep their powder dry until more clarity over Brexit emerges.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options‘Arab governments have been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate’Click to followThe IndependentAn ominous warning that Middle Eastern governments “have been given free rein to continue silencing the media” has been published by The Washington Post two weeks after the disappearance of its author, Saudi dissident journalist Jamal&nbspKhashoggi.Mr Khashoggi’s column was published on Wednesday, a little over a fortnight since he was last seen, crossing the threshold of the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.It was released hours after a gruesome account in Turkey’s pro-government&nbspYeni&nbspSafak&nbspnewspaper alleged Saudi officials had cut off Mr Khashoggi’s fingers and then decapitated him inside the consulate while his fiancee waited outside.Jamal Khashoggi: ‘What the Arab world needs most is free expression’The Saudi government, including its crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, has denied all involvement in the face of international outrage at his disappearance.In an introduction to the column, the&nbspPost’s global opinions editor, Karen Attiah, said she received the essay from Mr Khashoggi’s translator and assistant the day after he was reported missing.In the op-ed, titled “Jamal Khashoggi: What the Arab world needs most is free expression”,&nbspMr Khashoggi recounted the imprisonment of a prominent writer who spoke against the Saudi establishment, and cited an incident in which the Egyptian government seized control of a newspaper.&nbsp“These actions no longer carry the consequence of a backlash from the international community. Instead, these actions may trigger condemnation quickly followed by silence,” he wrote.&nbsp“As a result, Arab governments have been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate.”&nbspPompeo arrives in Saudi Arabia to discuss Jamal Khashoggi disappearanceIn the column, Mr Khashoggi, a Saudi citizen who went into self-imposed exile in the US following&nbspthe rise of the crown prince, also discussed the practice of Middle Eastern governments blocking internet access to keep tight control of the information their citizens can see.&nbsp“The Arab world is facing its own version of an Iron Curtain, imposed not by external actors but through domestic forces vying for power,” he wrote.&nbspSuspects in Khashoggi case ‘tied to Saudi Crown Prince or his circle’Turkey seeks to reshape ties with US and Saudi over missing journalistIMF chief pulls out of Saudi conference amid missing journalist stormInside the kingdom, Saudis rattled by handling of Jamal Khashoggi caseHe praised the Post for translating many of his columns into Arabic and said it was important for Middle Easterners to be able to read about democracy in the West.He also said it was critical&nbspArab voices had&nbspa platform from which to be heard.&nbsp“We suffer from poverty, mismanagement and poor education,” Mr Khashoggi wrote. “Through the creation of an independent international forum, isolated from the influence of nationalist governments spreading hate through propaganda, ordinary people in the Arab world would be able to address the structural problems their societies face.”Mr Khashoggi&nbspstarted writing for the&nbspPost’s&nbspopinion section in September 2017 and his columns often criticised the prince and direction the Saudi kingdom was taking.&nbspCreated with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Smoke billows following an Israeli air strike around the southern Gaza Strip city of Rafah. moving between the consulate and the residence nearly two hours after Mr Khashoggi’s&nbsparrival.&nbspJamal Khashoggi could have been work of ‘rogue killers’Donald Trump, who initially warned of “severe punishment” if the kingdom was found to be behind the disappearance, said on Wednesday the US wanted Turkey to turn over any audio or video recording it had of Mr Khashoggi’s&nbspalleged murder “if it exists”.He recently suggested the global community had jumped to conclusions that Saudi Arabia was behind Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, comparing them to the accusations of sexual assault made during the confirmation of his pick for Supreme Court justice, Brett Kavanaugh.Amid the growing&nbspinternational backlash&nbspfollowing Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, several prominent business and technology leaders have pulled out of an investment conference in Riyadh dubbed “Davos in the Desert”.On Wednesday, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Christine title: Brexit news Jaguar Land Rover Solihull Birmingham Slovakia tata motors leave EU
story: The country's biggest carmaker said the &ldquofluctuating global market has triggered the decision to temporarily close down its Solihull plant from October 22, sparking a furious response from UK politicians amid the Slovakian investment.The closure comes off the back of plans to shift all production of JLR&rsquos Discovery model to Slovakia from the West Midlands site, and a fall in demand for diesel cars amid concern over emissions.A number of MPs and MEPs have spoken exclusively to Express to voice their concern over the closure and investment in Slovakia.Independent MEP Jonathan Arnott, who defected from Ukip in January this year, said: &ldquoIt seems that the rules change according to who is doing the asking when it comes to the European Commission.                'He is making it up!' Brexiteer MP savages &pound1.2bn Jaguar profit loss                Jaguar Land Rover workers put on THREE-DAY week &ldquoGiving money to a company to effectively relocate from one country to another sounds like a textbook definition of distorting competition under Article 107 of the TFEU to me.&ldquoThe Single Market has never been a level playing field.&ldquoThe sooner we&rsquore properly out of the European Union and able to set our own policies, the better.Roger Godsiff, Labour MP for Birmingham Hall Green, said: &ldquoIt seems quite clear to me that the owners of Jaguar Land Rover, Tata Motors Limited India, are seeking to transfer a large part of their operations, possibly as a precursor to transferring all their operations, to a low-wage part of the EU.The EU has approved a huge state aid package to help fund a Slovakian JLR plant (Image: )The factory floor at the Solihull plant  (Image: )&ldquoThis is a typical &lsquorace to the bottom&rsquo.&ldquoJaguar Land Rover has a highly skilled and well-paid workforce in this country who have been loyal to the car manufacturer for many years.&ldquoBut Tata Motors Limited only appear to be interested in the &lsquobottom line&rsquo and if they can make more money out of transferring their production to a low-wage country, while also picking up handsome inducements from the Government there, then they have no hesitation in doing so and little concern about the impact on their loyal workforce here.West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge has also lashed out at the news.                'UK ON BRINK of striking Brexit deal with EU' Former MEP says Workers on the factory floor at the Solihull Jaguar Land Rover plant (Image: )The Libertarian Party UK Deputy Chairman said: &ldquoOnce again we see EU investment into industry to the detriment of the UK.&ldquoThose begging for the opportunity to remain in this monstrous monolith really should start noting what is going on.&ldquoThis socialist union of European states will not be happy until parity is achieved between the pieces of land formerly known as nations.&ldquoIf that requires reducing the UK economy to the level of states recovering from years behind the Iron Curtain, then that is what they do.&ldquoAs for Jaguar, they should know better. Their drop in profits has come largely due to an over-investment in diesel engines which are now being persecuted by the very EU who pertain to be helping them.East Midlands Ukip MEP Jonathan Bullock said this latest development was not the first time the EU had acted in such a way.He said: &ldquoIn 2012 the European Investment Bank loaned Ford &pound80million to develop a Transit factory in Turkey - Ford thus closed its plant in Southampton.&ldquoThe EU is fundamentally hostile to the interests of British workers.&ldquoWorse, as long as we are paying into the European Union, British taxpayers are subsidising the transfer of British jobs, be it to Turkey or Slovakia.MEPs and MPs have reacted furiously to the news (Image: )&ldquoWe cannot leave this farce, soon enough.However, Dame Caroline Spelman, Conservative MP for Meriden and the West Midlands, who meets with JLR regularly, explained the Solihull plant&rsquos temporary closure was to allow it to &ldquoundertake wholesale change to prepare for electrification.She said: &ldquoThe upgrade of the Solihull plant will mean it is at the forefront of electric and hybrid car production, which is where the future of car production lies.Jaguar Land Rover has been contacted for comment.

story: EU summit: Emmanuel Macaron and Angela Merkel enjoy a late night beer  (Image: TWITTER@hkresic)The French president and German Chancellor were photographed alongside Belgian prime minster Charles Michel and Luxembourg leader Xavier Bettel knocking back a pint or two in the centre of Brussels.&nbspThe group looked cosy as they enjoyed their late night beverage among tourists in Grand Place.The pub stop came just after Brussels bosses enjoyed a dinner, which Prime Minister Theresa May was excluded from, to discuss their next steps in the Brexit process following an EU summit.READ MORE: BREXIT LIVE&nbsp                Meghan Markle and Prince Harry Australia tour LIVEMrs May travelled to Brussels on Wednesday in the hope of breaking the longstanding deadlock in negotiations, specifically around the Irish border.There, EU leaders raised the possibility that the post-Brexit transition period, during which Britain would retain EU rules, could be extended by a year as a way to give London more time to agree the EU-UK customs deal it wants to solve the issue of the Irish border.But Mrs May has repeatedly ruled out extending the transition period.And this morning was no different when the Prime Minister insisted Britain won&rsquot need an extension to the Brexit transition period and can have a future relationship in place with the EU by the end of December 2020.EU summit: Angela Merkel and Emmanuel greet each other  (Image:  )She told reporters this morning: We have made good progress on withdrawal agreement and future partnership.On the withdrawal agreement there are issues remaining on the backstop.The original proposal put forward by the EU was one we could not have accepted in the UK, it would have created a customs border down the Irish sea. Earlier in the year, we put forward a proposal as how to deal with this issue - a further idea has now emerged.A further idea at this stage is to extend the implementation period for a matter of months and only for a matter of months but the point is this is not expected to be used - because we are working to ensure we have that future relationship in place by the end of December 2020. story: The model flew in from Dubai after working and socialising with accessories designer Bulgari.Pushing two large suitcases and one small case Lady Kitty was seen arriving at Perth Airport.She wore jeans, a grey t-shirt and camouflage jacket along with sunglasses and a red Bulgari handbag.Just two days earlier she had been seen modelling a silver version of the bag on the sand dunes of Dubai.                Meghan Markle shows growing baby bump in &pound8289 outfit                Meghan Markle in pictures: Duke and Duchess of Sussex hit the beachThe aristocratic fashion model is in Australia to support the Channel 7 Charity fundraising Perth Telethon on October 20 and 21.The 36 hour fundraising drive is the biggest telethon in the world and raises money for children who suffer life-threatening diseases.With the event starting on Saturday, there is time for Lady Kitty to meet with Prince Harry and Meghan, who are in Australia until Tuesday October 23.The newlyweds are in Sydney until Saturday before they head off to Fraser Island on Monday October 22.Princess Diana's niece Lady Kitty Spencer is in Australia while Meghan and Harry are on tour (Image: SPLASH)Lady Kitty Spencer is in Australia for Channel 7's charity telethon (Image: SPLASH)Today they have already visited Government House, a social enterprise cafe, and visited school children in Melbourne.They travelled on an iconic Melbourne tram to South Melbourne beach to meet volunteers from a beach patrol programme.They spoke about &ldquofast fashion as they saw how beaches had become awash with plastic.Students from Albert Park primary school and Albert Park college - who had been helping to keep the beach tidy - showed the couple bags containing plastic cups, bottles and straws which they had found in the sand.Lady Kitty Spencer flew in to Australia from Dubai (Image: SPLASH)The duke said: There is literally plastic everywhere. And, you know, microplastics are a real problem, especially the microplastics from fast-fashion. Did you know that's one of the biggest culprits?Meghan told the pupils: It's amazing what you guys are doing.Well done, you're doing a really great job. Keep it up.The couple then strolled hand in hand towards an assembled group of lifeguards with one, Sebastian Top, asking if they were going for a dip.Maybe not today, laughed Meghan, who was wearing eco-friendly shoes made from recycled water bottles by Rothy's.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry attend a beach cleanup on South Melbourne Beach as Lady Kitty arrives (Image: )Harry pointed to a group of around 30 people who had waded into the sea from the beach to get a better view of them.He said: If we try and swim, I think they might be a bit of a hazard.After Fraser Island, the pair will head to Fiji and Tonga from Tuesday October 23, before a quick stop back in Sydney, Australia for the Invictus Games closing ceremony.The games are special to Harry and Meghan, who made their first public appearance as a couple at last year&rsquos games in Toronto, Canada.They then head to New Zealand on Sunday October 28, with Wellington, Abel Tasman, Auckland and Rotorua on the itinerary.The royal tour is their first as a married couple and shows the pair forging out their roles as ambassadors for the youth and the Commonwealth.

I've loved that family since I was eight and I've followed them around the world.&ldquoHe reciprocated the hug as well, it wasn&rsquot just a little&hellipit was awesome.Ms Brown admitted: I didn't expect it to happen because it's actually against protocol.Royal news: Prince Harry gave a young fan a very well received hug  (Image: na)Ms Brown also told reporters that she rated the hug as &ldquothe best ever.The Royal couple met members of the public during a walkabout at the Royal Botanical Gardens and Government House Drive in Melbourne.They arrived in the south Australian city on Thursday for a day of engagements and managed to shake hands with hundreds of well-wishers despite being delayed by heavy traffic.The Prince was also pictured playing with young children, and the Duchess was gifted numerous bunches of flowers and a teddy bear.One girl was dressed up as a princess, in a blue satin gown, mock crown and bouquet of flowers.The Royal couple were in Melbourne to meet a number of charities, including youth leaders and community members from the 'This Girl Can' and 'The Man Cave' programmes during a reception at Government House.The Duke and Duchess were greeted by Governor of Victoria Linda Dessau upon their arrival at Government House.They watched demonstrations in the gardens of the venue from participants of the This Girl Can programme, which aims to get women involved in sport.

title: stephen hawking brief answers to big questions interstellar travel
story: Stephen Hawking: Forget Mars - humans can conquer MILKY WAY by 2200 (Image: )In his final book Prof Hawking left behind a series of forecasts and warnings which could effect the human race.One such problem is that Earth is becoming overpopulated and runaway climate change will destroy our planet.For this reason, many experts such as Elon Musk and NASA have set their sights on colonising nearby celestial bodies such as Mars and the moon in order to ensure humanity&rsquos future.Prof Hawking, however, left behind much more ambitious missions, and believes in as little as 200 years, humans will have conquered interstellar travel and can begin colonising the Milky Way.                END OF THE WORLD: Stephen Hawking's dire warning the Earth is DOOME                Is time travel possible? Stephen Hawking reveals time travel BOMBSHELLIn his final book, Brief Answers to the Big Questions, Prof Hawking says humanity&rsquos first stop outside of the solar system could be Proxima b &ndash some 25 TRILLION miles away.With todays technology, it could take up to three million years to reach the planet orbiting Proxima Centauri, but in 200 years it could take as little as a decade, says the former theoretical physicist.Prof Hawking wrote: &ldquoProxima b, for example, &hellip is the closest exoplanet to Earth but still four and a half light years away, and recent research indicates that it has some similarities to Earth.&ldquoTravelling to these candidate worlds isn&rsquot possible perhaps with today&rsquos technology, but by using our imagination, we can make interstellar travel a long-term aim &ndash in the next 200 to 500 years.The former Cambridge professor also claimed in his book that God does not exist.He described his claim there is no afterlife or higher power as a &ldquoprofound realisation.Professor Hawking wrote in the newly-published book: &ldquoWe are free to believe what we want, and it&rsquos my view that the simplest explanation is that there is no God.&ldquoNo one created the universe and no one directs our fate.Proxima b could be our first stop outside the Solar System, says Prof Hawking (Image: )&ldquoThis leads me to a profound realisation: there is probably no heaven and afterlife either.&ldquoI think belief in the afterlife is just wishful thinking.Professor Hawking died at the age of 76 in the early hours of March 14 following a long battle with motor neurone disease.Professor Hawking died at the age of 76 in the early hours of March 14 (Image: )He suffered from a rare early-onset slow-progressing form of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as motor neurone disease or Lou Gehrig's disease.He was diagnosed with MND in 1963 at the age of 21.Doctors expected him to live for only two more years, but he had a form of the disease which progressed more slowly than usual.

story: The German politician urged the top Eurocrat to offer Britain a new arrangement putting an end to freedom of movement, suggesting the change in strategy could stop Brexit.Mr Henkel implored Donald Tusk to step over his own shadow to reach a satisfactory withdrawal agreement with the UK &ndash claiming the end of free travel between the European Union and the UK might convince Brexiteers to backtrack on plans to leave the bloc.Speaking to Sky News, the German MEP said: President Tusk talked about a Gordian knot and he is right. I appeal to Mr Tusk to behave like Alexander the Great. He should cut this Gordian knot, he should step over his own shadow and offer Britain now a different solution when it comes to freedom of movement.This is either good for a better deal under the assumption of Brexit but it would also be good in case Britain changes its mind. Even the Brexiteers could then say &lsquook, we got what we always wanted without the disadvantages of Brexit.                Italian diplomat demands Britons 'satisfy EU needs' in heated TV clashMr Henkel insisted Brussels should stop behaving unreasonably and arrogantly, providing Britain with an alternative arrangement which would justify a new vote on membership to the EU.He continued: The European Union is behaving unreasonably at times and I think, sometimes, very arrogantly. In this particular case, however, I don&rsquot see any real solution.My suggestion is the Commission stops linking trade always with freedom of movement, offers Britain a new deal and then give Britain the chance to rethink their decision.The German politician also rejected plans set forward by EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier to extend the Brexit transition period to December 2020.Brexit news: Mr Henkel implored Mr Tusk to offer Britain a new deal on freedom of movement (Image: SKY NEWS&bullEBS)Mr Henkel added: Extending that period by another year does not help. What would help is right now, if there was no deal by tomorrow and the next two weeks, the European Union offers Britain more time to negotiate.In other words, don&rsquot take this date of March 2019 too seriously. Give them a little bit more time to come up with a deal.Delay Article 50 because that is better than a no deal Brexit. No deal Brexit would be a total disaster for both, Britain and also the European Union.Mr Tusk revealed negotiations have become &ldquomore complicated than was previously predicted as both sides reach yet another impasse on the Irish border conundrum.The warning came in his invitation letter to European leaders, who will gather in the Belgian capital on Wednesday evening for crunch discussions about the United Kingdom&rsquos orce from the EU.Negotiations are currently &ldquopaused as both sides struggle to agree on the highly disputed Irish backstop, according to a senior EU diplomat.

title: Brexit news UK EU latest deal vote Angela Merkel Michel Barnier summit Brussels
story: The European Union summit got underway in Brussels on Wednesday and Brexit remains on the agenda as talks between Michel Barnier and Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab failed to break the Brexit deadlock on Sunday.German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Wednesday she believes a Brexit deal is still possible as she highlighted Germany&rsquos preparation for a no deal Brexit.When asked whether the EU will be more flexible than they have been in the past, Mr Henkel said: &ldquoNot really. The trouble with Mrs Merkel, the Chancellor, is that she left, so far, the entire initiative to Barnier.&ldquoAnd Barnier, I think, has treated Britain in the last couple of months not with enough respect and with a little arrogance.                Brexiteer MEP says ANY Brexit deal would be better than THIS option                Brexit news: Ireland CONCEDES on backstop as May seals another victory&ldquoLet&rsquos face it. After Brexit Britain is going to be the EU&rsquos largest single customer, ahead of the United States and ahead of China.&ldquoYou don&rsquot treat a potential customer like Barnier did. So I think she has abdicated this whole thing to Brussels.&ldquoAnd my suspicion is she is not going to change that.&ldquoShe is very weak in her own party these days after the recent elections in Bavaria.Brexit news: Hans-Olaf Henkel said Angela Merkel is weak (Image: &bullBBC)But Mr Henkel claimed there is now only &ldquoone conclusion and that is to follow the advice of Lord Heseltine, Nick Clegg and Tony Blair and have another Brexit referendum.He called for the EU to &ldquogive Britain what they have always wanted in order to keep them as a member of the Brussels bloc.The German MEP said a no deal Brexit would be a &ldquocatastrophe as he demanded the EU offer Britain with a better deal.Mr Henkel added: &ldquoSo they&rsquoll have what they always wanted without Brexit that gives Remainers an opportunity to get more initiative for a new referendum and gives the Brexiteers in Britain a possibility for a face-saving way out because a democracy which can&rsquot change its mind, in my opinion, ceases to be a democracy.Tony Blair, Michael Heseltine and Nick Clegg have bizarrely chosen a host of European newspapers to demand a second Brexit referendum in Britain.They claim Brexit negotiations have not gone well and now the public need to make a &ldquofinal decision, saying: &ldquoOur domestic debate is far from over and, even at this late hour, many of us are continuing to make the case that the British public need to make the final decision once we are in possession of all the relevant facts.&ldquoSo we ask our European partners to be ready to give us the space and time, if necessary, to make such a final decision.&ldquoThe demand for a &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo on the outcome of the negotiations will continue to grow.&ldquoThe politics of all this influx and now is not the time to shut down options either for Britain or Europe.The Irish border remains the major sticking point in Brexit negotiations with the so-called backstop threatening to produce a border down the Irish Sea.Donald Tusk, the President of the European Council, has already warned there are &ldquono grounds for optimism of a breakthrough in Brexit negotiations.

title: Brexit news latest UK EU no deal Ireland backstop border Theresa May David Davis vote
story: David Davis pledged his support for the StandUp4Brexit campaign on Wednesday as he urged Theresa May to drop her controversial Brexit blueprint.&nbspThe former Brexit Secretary said: &ldquoI&rsquom delighted to back the #StandUp4Brexit campaign along with so many of my colleagues in the House of Commons.&ldquoIt&rsquos clear that the Chequers proposals don&rsquot have support either in the House of Commons or indeed the EU.&ldquoThey&rsquore objected to by people who used to be Leavers and by people who used to be Remainers.                Furious Brexiteers DEMAND UK get out of EU NOW                 Brexiteer MP points finger at EU for politicising KEY Brexit issue&ldquoSo clearly it&rsquos time to find a new start, a reset, a new policy to put to the EU.The Tory MP added: &ldquoWe need a new approach to the Article 50 negotiations and so it&rsquos time for the Prime Minister to go back to the principals she laid out in the Lancaster House speech and come up with a new policy.&ldquoWhich in essence will be the Freetrade+ or Canada+++ approach which will actually meet the requirements of both Britain and the European Union.&ldquoThis will be popular with voters, will be acceptable to the EU and it will be supported by our supporters, our voters, out in the country.Brexit news: the former Brexit secretary said Theresa May needs to  (Image: Getty)&ldquoIt&rsquos time to chuck Chequers, come up with a new policy and deliver a real Brexit.President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani told reporters the EU parliament will vote down every deal which doesn't avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.Despite praising Theresa May's tone, which he described as much more positive and willing to cooperate than the one she used at the end of the summit in Salzburg, Mr Tajani said her speech failed to meet his expectations.The deal proposed by the British prime minister, he said, would see the single market crippled, which is something the EU can't accept.He said: Mrs May gave messages of desire of reaching an agreement, the political tone was right but I didn't find substantial changes on the contents of her speech.We can't accept our single market to be torn apart, we defend the unity of the freedoms it grants, of movement and of goods.However, Mr Tajani&nbsphe said there is still time to find a deal and that the EU wants to maintain good relationship with the UK.He added: We want good relations. We are friends, the UK will leave the EU but not Europe.We want to have very good relations with the UK in the future on security and counter-terrorism, for example.

story: The Luxembourgish politician swiftly dismissed suggestions the extension of the Brexit transition deal into December 2021 means the UK remains a member of the EU.Mr Bettel also warned Theresa May times is running out on striking a deal, urging her to address the issues raised by the Commission in regards to the future trade arrangement with the bloc.Addressing the press ahead of a crunch meeting in Brussels, he said: On 29th March it&rsquos game over.The 29th March is the last day the United Kingdom is a member of the European Union. We are waiting for his go to have another meeting.We&rsquore not under pressure. The UK Government knows what are the problems, they also have to move. They know the two points where we have the problem on the internal market.He added: You can&rsquot be out and having all the same things as if you were a family member. That&rsquos the problem. They know what the problem is.Arriving at the European Council summit in Brussels on Thursday, Prime Minister Theresa May said that the option had emerged to extend the Brexit transition period for a matter of months, but that she still expected it to conclude at the end of 2020.Brexit news: Mr Bettel warned Theresa May  (Image: )European Parliament president Antonio Tajani said that Theresa May spoke about an extended transition period in Wednesday night's address to EU leaders, but not in favour or against.Mrs May said that the UK had already put forward a proposal to avoid the need for either a hard border or a customs border down the Irish Sea.And she added: A further idea that has emerged - and it is an idea at this stage - is to create an option to extend the implementation period for a matter of months - and it would only be for a matter of months.But the point is that this is not expected to be used, because we are working to ensure that we have that future relationship in place by the end of December 2020. A further idea has now emerged.We of course are working to ensure not just that we are able to ensure no hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, were such a gap in time to emerge, but to ensure that the implementation period comes to an end in December 2020, because we are able to put the future relationship into place at the end of the implementation period and ensure no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.He said that the European Parliament would support any proposal for a three-year transition.Mr Tajani, who was meeting Taoiseach Leo Varadkar in the margins of the summit on Thursday morning, warned that the Parliament would not vote for a Brexit deal which did not include a backstop arrangement for the Irish border.Brexit news: Boris Johnson joined David Davis in warning Mrs May  (Image: )Boris Johnson and David Davis have warned Mrs May voters will not forgive her if she surrenders to Brussels in Brexit negotiations,In an open letter to the Prime Minister, the former Foreign Secretary and Brexit Secretary claim her plans for a future relationship with the EU are less popular than the poll tax, urging her to deliver the Brexit which people voted for.The letter was signed by Jacob-Rees Mogg, as well as former Cabinet ministers Iain Duncan Smith, Owen Paterson and Priti Patel.The letter, published by the Daily , states: We urge you to make clear that you will not bind the UK into the purgatory of perpetual membership of the EU's customs union, whether by a backstop or any other route.Talk of either a UK or a Northern Irish backstop is inimical to our status as a sovereign nation-state. Both are unnecessary: indeed they are a trap being set by the EU which it is vital we do not fall into.

story: Brexit news: Theresa May admits backstop cannot contain time limit (Image: PA)Express understands the Prime Minister acknowledges the European Union&rsquos backstop drafted in the December withdrawal agreement can not feature an end date.Senior EU officials revealed Mrs May made the admission to Leo Varadkar before briefing the remaining EU leaders on her latest Brexit strategy.Mr Varadkar insisted a &ldquolegally operative backstop that would come into effect immediately after the transition period must still be included in the withdrawal agreement in order for it to be acceptable to Ireland.This has remained a Brussels demand as the bloc&rsquos leaders seek assurances Brexit will not create a hard border on the island of Ireland.Mr Varadkar did, however, move to offer the Prime Minister an opportunity to back the backstop more palatable in Westminster by using creative wording.&ldquoThere can&rsquot be a time-limit to it, said one official. &ldquoBut we can try to find a wording to show it&rsquoll never be used.Yesterday&rsquos meeting with the Irish prime minister was one of four bilateral discussions held by Mrs May on the fringes of the European Council summit in Brussels.In her address to her European counterparts, the Prime Minister risked infuriating Brexiteers by declaring her willingness to consider extending the transition period as a potential answer to the Irish border issue.                EU chief Tajani demands THREE YEARS of transition and May not against                &lsquoMarch is GAME OVER for Brexit&rsquo Luxembourg leader offers May ULTIMATUMAccording to another official, Mrs May was &ldquoopen to the plain it helps but didn&rsquot take ownership.A third source added: &ldquoA senior EU official said: There were no new proposals.&ldquoShe also mentioned the transition period.&ldquoShe said the UK would be ready to consider the extension of the transition period.The Prime Minister&rsquos attempt to kickstart negotiations ended with EU leaders shelving plans for an emergency summit in November, saying not enough progress had been made in the talks.The 27 leaders note that, despite intensive negotiations, not enough progress has been achieved, one EU official present at the talks said.The official said that the leaders stood ready to convene a European Council, if and when the Union negotiator reports that decisive progress has been made.The official added: For now, the 27 are not planning to organise an extraordinary summit on Brexit in November.

title: Scrapping free TV licence over 75s cruel
story: More than 4.46 million homes with older residents receive a free TV licence, saving them &pound150.50 (Image: Scott BarbourGetty Images)A discussion paper commissioned by the BBC has described the concession as no longer justified as the wealth of over-75s had improved significantly.It insisted there had been profound economic changes since the benefit was introduced and noted that pensioners are now the least likely age group to live in poverty.But the proposal prompted widespread and immediate criticism from campaigners and charities who pointed out that many older people live in poverty and rely on their televisions to combat loneliness.Latest figures show 1.9 million pensioners still live in poverty &ndash including nearly one in five over-75s.                Woman, 86, suffers heart attack after purse snatched from bag in sh...As many as 3.6 million older people in the UK live alone, more than two million of whom are 75-plus, and one in four older people views the television as their main form of companionship.Dame Esther said: The Silver Line receives thousands of calls from older people through the evening, especially on long winter nights when the TV is their only friend.They have paid the licence fee all their lives &ndash this is the way the BBC can give something back.National Pensioners Convention general secretary Jan Shortt called on the Government to take the licence concession back in-house.Miss Shortt said: Ever since George Osborne forced the BBC to take over responsibility for the free TV licence, we have known that they would try and get rid of it.Dame Esther Rantzen campaigns for older people (Image: Jeff SpicerGetty )Frankly it's not the job of the broadcaster to administer or fund part of our wider welfare policy. That is a job for government and it needs to be returned to the most suitable department as a matter of urgency.Laura Alcock-Ferguson of the Campaign to End Loneliness, said: Television provides a great comfort for many lonely older people.It can give structure and routine and make you feel as though you're part of something. The prospect of that being taken away could have a devastating impact on older people experiencing loneliness.More than 4.46 million homes with older residents receive a free TV licence, saving them &pound150.50 a year.But the BBC is reported to be preparing proposals on reforming the subsidy, which could include raising the age of eligibility and means-testing.Options could also include asking for voluntary payments and removing the subsidy from pensioners who live with younger family.The report by Frontier Economics, on behalf of the BBC, says by 2022 the cost to the corporation will be &pound745million - more than double the &pound365million paid by the Government in 2002.Former Labour business minister Ian Lucas yesterday urged Theresa May to halt any cuts. The Prime Minister said it was up to the BBC to take a decision about how they operate on this.The broadcaster's report says when the concession was introduced, it was justified based on evidence that older pensioner households were disproportionately concentrated at the bottom of the income distribution.It also says: Incomes, wealth and life expectancy of older people have improved significantly. Pensioner poverty rates have fallen, and older households report higher wellbeing on a range of metrics.These changes give cause for reflection on what an appropriate approach to providing concessionary licences to older households might look like.A BBC spokesman said: There are important issues to consider. We will do nothing without consulting with the public. title: Brexit news UK latest Nick Boles Theresa May Brexit transition period extension EU
story: The Prime Minister has been left on the brink of accepting a proposal from Brussels of extending the transition period following Brexit until December 2021 to provide more time to resolve the Irish border issue - a move initially floated by the EU&rsquos chief negotiator&nbspMichel Barnier.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, Mr Boles attacked Theresa May's Brexit plans have failed to deliver, leading to humiliating concessions.Mr Boles also said a possible extension of the Brexit transition period could cost the UK billions more than some have feared.&nbspMr Boles said: &ldquoLet&rsquos focus on the price for a minute. The price of an extra year people agree is not going to be 10 billion euros, it&rsquos going to be 18 billion extra euros because we enter a new budget period for the EU when contributions are going up.                Brexit news: May concedes Irish backstop CANNOT be time-limited                'Warrior Woman' Theresa May adopts style &lsquosimilar to Tony Blair&rsquo &ldquoSo that&rsquos 18 billion euros for a single extra 12 months, to secure an agreement that we were told previously would only require us to be in a transition period until December 2020.Mr Boles continued: &ldquoThe alternative that I and now others are proposing is instead of this very expensive transition, that we go into the EEA and EFTA, in a position like Norway&rsquos, and from there we&rsquoll negotiate our relationship.&ldquoIt would have the huge advantage of having lower contributions, a good deal less than full members of the EU because it is not a part of the Common Agricultural Policy.&lsquoIf we were in that position it would be up to us to decide when we were ready to move on, and it would be much, much less expensive.Brexit news: Nick Boles claimed that an extension to the transition period could cost &euro18 billion (Image: Getty )Prime Minister Theresa May travelled to Brussels on Wednesday in the hope of breaking the longstanding deadlock in&nbspBrexit&nbspnegotiations, specifically around the Irish border.Mrs May has suggested the Brexit implantation period may need to be extended by a number of months in order to reach an agreement on key issues such as the Irish border.Ms May told reporters this morning: As I said, we have made good progress on withdrawal agreement and future partnership.On the withdrawal agreement, there are issues remaining on the backstop.The original proposal put forward by the&nbspEuropean Union&nbspwas one we could not have accepted in the UK, it would have created a customs border down the Irish sea. Earlier in the year, we put forward a proposal as how to deal with this issue - a further idea has now emerged.A further idea at this stage is to extend the implementation period for a matter of months and only for a matter of months but the point is this is not expected to be used - because we are working to ensure we have that future relationship in place by the end of December 2020.I am clear that it is possible to deliver - there will be no need for any proposal of this sort - and the implementation will end by the end of 2020.The change would mean the UK remaining within the single market and customs union, while being subjected to EU rules and regulation for almost three years after the official Brexit date of March 29, 2019 - and more than five years after the referendum vote to Leave.Furious Brexiteers said the move would add another delay to when the UK could sign new trade deals around the world and would cost taxpayers billions of pounds in additional contributions to the EU.

title: babes in the wood russell bishop nicola fellowes karen hadaway
story: Nicola Fellows and Karen Hadaway were both nine when they were murdered (Image: nc)Bishop is accused of sexually assaulting and strangling nine-year-olds Karen Hadaway and Nicola Fellows in woods at Wild Park in the Brighton suburb of Moulsecoomb, in October 1986.Hours after they were found, Bishop spoke to neighbour Geoffrey Caswell, the Old Bailey heard.Mr Caswell thought the defendant seemed grief-stricken, said Brian Altman QC, prosecuting. If he did appear grief-stricken, then he was play-acting.A friend later asked Bishop if the experience had upset him. The defendant told his friend it did not bother him at all, said Mr Altman.Bishop, now 52, was cleared of the murders at Lewes Crown Court in 1987.Less than three years later, he kidnapped a seven-year-old girl as she roller-skated to a shop in nearby Whitehawk.He bundled the girl into the boot of his Ford Cortina and drove her for 14 miles to Devil's Dyke on the South Downs in West Sussex, the jury was told.He forced her into the back seat and throttled her with his bare hands, Mr Altman said.Russell Bishop, 52, is accused of murdering two nine-year-old girls (Image: Sussex PolicePA)As the little girl fell unconscious, he stripped and sexually assaulted her before leaving her for dead in dense gorse bushes, the jury was told.She later identified Bishop who was convicted of attempted murder, indecent assault and kidnapping.Bishop is being retried for the murders of Karen and Nicola, following new evidence which led to his 1987 acquittal being quashed by the Court of Appeal.The Old Bailey jury was told crucial DNA evidence had been discovered on Karen's left arm.A light blue Pinto sweatshirt, allegedly discarded near the scene by Bishop, linked him to the murders, the court heard.He has denied the garment was his.Key exhibits including the sweatshirt and the girls' clothing were examined for fibres and trace evidence using sticky tape, the jury heard.Mr Altman said: The tapings represent a time capsule. They are devastating for the defendant.Police and scenes of crime officers at the scene of the crime in 1986 (Image: Press Association)Fibres from the girls' tops and a skirt belonging to Bishop's 16-yearold girlfriend were found on the sweatshirt, Mr Altman said.He added: Quite simply, its wearer, the defendant, wore it at the time of the murders and he was their killer.Bishop, of Hollingdean, Brighton, denies two counts of murder.Jurors heard he joined the search for the girls and was nearby when they were found lying together.Bishop tried to get closer but another searcher ordered him back.He later described the scene to police in so much detail, he must be the killer, Mr Altman added. He said he saw blood-coloured foam on Nicky's lips, he said.There is simply no possibility he could have been in possession of the detail of the precise situation and positioning of the girls and the foam on Nicola's lips unless he had seen it with his own eyes from very close.He was able to describe what he did because that is how he left those two little girls, having killed and sexually assaulted them.Bruising suggested the killer had punched Nicola in the face, said Mr Altman.He added that the killer had strangled the girls with one or both hands.The trial continues.

story: California students baked cookies with cremated ashes in (Image: )At least nine high school pupils ate the cookies before it was known what was inside them.The teenage bakers then revealed their grisly ingredients to shocked youngsters at Da Vinci Charter Academy, west of Sacramento, California.One classmate Andy Knox told KCRA television station: I didn't believe her until she pulled out the urn. She told me there's a special ingredient in the cookie. Two cars PLOUGH into store in California leaving MULTIPLE injuredThe stomach churning baking was thought to have been carried out by two youngsters.Police are investigating, but are not sure whether the pupils can be prosecuted and it is unlikely they will be prosecuted.Davis Police lieutenant Paul Doroshov told The Sacramento Bee it would probably take some legal debate to figure out.He admitted the pair probably would not be prosecuted, and said it was a school issue.The pupils attend Da Vinci Academy just west of Sacramento in California (Image: GOOGLE)In a letter to parents, headteacher Tyler Millsap said the pair were sorry and that it had become a personal family matter.He said: &ldquoI can say that those who were involved are remorseful and this is now a personal family matter and we want to respect the privacy of the families involved.No health implications had been reported, but Lieutenant Doroshov said there could be some emotional issues experienced.There is not a health risk to the wider community, headmaster Mr Millsap said.He added: We always take allegations of wrongdoing seriously and we conduct thorough investigations and involve the police or other entities when appropriate.Da Vinci Academy is in a small town called Davis, just west of Sacramento.

title: dussehra 2018 date celebrate navratri diwali hindu
story: Gods and Goddesses are worshipped during the festivities, which also mark the beginning of preparations for Diwali - the Hindu festival of lights.Dussehra, known as Vijayadashami in eastern and northeastern India, is an important Hindu festival held at the end of Navratri.The festival is being held today - October , .The festival celebrates the victory of good over evil , with people in eastern and northeastern states of India celebrating the goddess Durgas victory over the buffalo demon.Durga, the warrior goddess, is usually depicted riding a tiger and wielding many weapons in her eight arms.In the northern, southern and western states people remember the god Ramas victory over the demon Ravana, who had kidnapped his we Sita.Dussehra and Vijayadashami are held at the end of Navratri, a nine-day festival of worship, dance and music.In eastern and northeastern India Vijayadashami marks the end of the festival and is celebrated by carrying clay statues of gods and goddesses, including Durga, to water.Worshippers play music and chant before immersing the images in water.In northern, southern and western states Dussehra is celebrated by the burning huge effigies of the demon Ravana before setting off fireworks to celebrate the destruction of evil.The festivals of Dussehra and Vijayadashami also mark the start of preparations for Diwali, which is celebrated  days later.This year Diwali - the festival of light - will be observed on Wednesday, November .The festival celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over evil.Celebrations see neighbourhoods covered in lights, and homes are lit up with diyas - small clay oil lamps.These diyas are placed in the entrance of the home, often in  rows.

title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Mrs May has dreamed of being Prime Minister since she was a child.It’s a tough job. It means leading from the front, making swt decisions and rallying the country with confidence and authority in dficult times.Instead, Mrs May’s team talk like defeatists about parliamentary “arithmetic”. How can she push through a dficult Brexit against ferocious opposition without a commanding Commons majority  But who was responsible for that parliamentary arithmetic It was Theresa May alone who decided to call an unforced election and it was she who single-handedly blew it. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. They did not vote for us to stay half-in, half-out or to see our sovereignty handed over to foreign powers. To govern is to decide. Mrs May made a career out of being the strong and silent type.Many of her MPs worry she is actually weak, vacillating and inarticulate.We are becoming accustomed to ruthless “wet jobs” by authoritarian tyrannies such as Russia, North Korea and the People’s Republic of China, many of them “friends” of Jeremy Corbyn.But Saudi Arabia has always revelled in public and private bloodshed. When it comes to terrorism, all roads lead back to Riyadh.A respectable MP, who does not joke about such matters, tells me the Saudi Embassy in London once had a torture chamber in the basement.I wonderit still does Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories need to stand behind pm
story: On Wednesday, she flies to Brussels for the European Council summit.With mounting Cabinet unease over the prospect of a Customs Union fudge, it is, as one Government source puts it, “squeaky bum time”.Four potential ministerial resignations loom over fears Britain could be tied to a permanent Customs Union. And Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson and Scottish Secretary David Mundell could resignNorthern Ireland is granted special status in any EU deal.The DUP and Remain Tory MPs also threaten Mrs May’s survival.Brexit chief Dominic Raab flew to Brussels yesterday for last-ditch talks. We must secure a time-limit agreement for the temporary Customs Union — remaining in it by the next election would stop us from striking any meaningful trade deals outside the EU.Meanwhile, Tories threatening mutiny should consider what will happenthey try to oust the PM. It will spark a bloody leadership battle that will strengthen Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour.It could also lead to a General Election in which the Tories will likely be punished by an unforgiving public, irritated at being dragged to the polls yet again.This week the PM must present her solution to the Irish border and reiterate her commitment for a No Deal Brexit, in which our £billion cheque would be taken off the table.And the Tory party needs to stand firmly behind her — for now. Too much is at stakethey implode.BRITAIN has the steepest air tax in Europe.So it is right that politicians are calling on Philip Hammond to slash air passenger duty in the budget. Cutting it will make holidays cheaper for families who have been hit by pricier trips because of the weaker Pound.On long haul flights, there is a £ tax on an economy ticket. This is a huge leap from  when it was just £.There is no environmental justication, it is simply used to fill the Treasury’s coffers. Slashing it will also boost businesses hoping to sell products outside of the EU.It will show Brexit Britain is an outward-looking, global nation.We hope you’re listening, Mr Hammond.JEREMY Kyle was inspired to see a doctor after reading a Sun article about testicular cancer.Before that, the TV favourite had been hesitant to seek advice after he found a lump.One in  blokes will have testicular cancer in their letime.
