title: this is your brexit boudicca moment theresa its time to say on your way barnier like up yours delors
story: I could see where he was going with this. After all, as we remember from school, this ancient British queen rose up against the Roman Empire, winning battles, slaughtering enemies and forcing the Romans to contemplate leaving Britain all together.“But, hang on,” I replied. “Wasn’t Boudicca eventually defeated ”Whatever the details, my friend was right. It is time for Theresa May to call on her deepest reserves of defiance and stand up to the European Union.Brussels has rejected her Brexit proposals, insulted us at the recent Salzburg summit and wants to dismember the United Kingdom by effectively annexing Northern Ireland for itself.Theresa May’s respect towards the EU has been met consistently with contempt for Britain. She has wished Brussels every success, while they wish us nothing but failure and decline. She has suggested solutions while they point out problems. And she has taken her Government to the brink by proposing a future relationship that is hated by many of her own MPs and supporters.It is time, now, to stop.Her Chequers plan already goes too far. It would tie us to European laws, over which we would have no say, and force us to accept the rulings of the European Court of Justice.It would prevent us from taking our own decisions and making our economy more competitive. And it almost certainly stops us from striking our own trade deals.Worse still,the Government persists with Chequers, we will end up with something even worse: Chequers Minus, which could mean making annual payments to Brussels, complying with more EU laws and accepting liberal immigration rules that amount to continued free movement.The longer we pretend Chequers can survive, the worse the outcome will be. As we negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, Britain should be seeking watertight assurances about our future relationship. Without them, we will sign away a £billion orce payment without any confidence we will get a fair deal for the future.But the crisis the Prime Minister described to Parliament yesterday, and which the Cabinet will discuss today, is not about Chequers, but the so-called “backstop” — what should happen to Northern Irelandthere is no eventual agreement on the future relationship.The EU’s proposition is an outrage. If there is no deal on the future relationship, they expect Northern Ireland to remain inside the Customs Union and, in effect, the single market.That would mean, in trying to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, we would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. That’s right, a border within our own country to avoid having one with another.The backstop would mean politicians in the Republic have a say over laws in Northern Ireland, while politicians in Belfast and London would have none. And it effectively breaches the Good Friday Agreement, which demands that Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom is respected unless a majority of Northern Irish people vote for the reunication of Ireland.The one concession the EU seems willing to make is that the whole of the United Kingdom can remain inside the Customs Union, not just Northern Ireland.But it insists there can be no time limit, and no right for the UK to unilaterally withdraw from the backstop.In other words, we would be trapped inside the Customs Union — following laws over which we have no say, letting Brussels grant trading access to our market for other countries and leaving us unable to agree trade deals of our own — for ever.This, of course, has always been the EU’s game. They have cynically used the Northern Irish peace process to try to tie the whole of the United Kingdom to the EU’s rules and regulations. And in their naivety, our negotiators have walked straight into the trap.The PM needs to tell the EU to get stuffed. And she must go back to the drawing board. She must replace Chequers with an ambitious, Canada Plus, free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. She must insist that the Northern Irish solution lies with technology and policy that avoid checks at the border. And she must tear up the backstop.One alternative, still a compromise for Brexiteers like me, is to agree that the UK will remain inside the Customs Union for a period of up to five years while the appropriate systems are put into place.Critics will say the EU will never agree. Butthey cannot accept a trade deal consistent with their principles and which respects the integrity of their single market, we know they seek only a damaging deal for Britain, or no deal at all.Others will say the Government could not get this kind of plan through the Commons. But it stands a better chance than Chequers Minus.This was, in fact, the plan Theresa May first set out at Lancaster House in January .There, she warned against a Chequers-style deal, saying: “We do not seek to hold on to bits of membership as we leave” and “we will not have truly leftwe are not in control of our own laws”.And she warned against what the backstop demands. She insisted on creating “no new barriers to living and doing business within our own Union”, and warned against “an unlimited transitional status”, which she called a “kind of permanent political purgatory”.Instead, she sought “a comprehensive free trade agreement” and the freedom for “Britain to negotiate its own trade agreements” with other countries.In other words, she described the Canada Plus agreement that is prepared and drafted but gathering dust inside the Brexit Department.Many years ago, The Sun advised us to say “up yours, Delors” to a meddling European Commissioner. Today, the PM needs to find her inner Boudicca and say: “On your way, Barnier.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. Let’s just hope that German ice skater Paul Boll doesn’t take a shine to Jane Horrocks.THE SUN has ­partnered with the Movember Foundation to help raise funds and awareness for men’s health issues by ­encouraging people to grow a sponsored ­moustache.Count me in.Post-menopause, this is the look I’m aiming for.AN “invisible” super-yacht has been invented for ­billionaires who value their privacy.Costing £million, it is coated in mirrored glass which, according to the designer, makes it “disappear between water and sea”.Er, doesn’t that mean other vessels will smash into it Still, at least it will sink ­privately. KATE SILVERTON asks her six-year-old daughter each day: “How did you fail today ”The Strictly contestant, who advocates taking kids outside their comfort zone by trying boxing or climbing, adds: “You are not ­trying hard enoughyou haven’t failed.”Perhaps give skying a miss though, eh ANT McPARTLIN and estranged we Lisa ­Armstrong received their decree nisi yesterday.Meaning that in six weeks’ time, the petitioner can apply for the decree absolute as long as everyone is agreed on the ision of cash and assets.In other words – as anyone who’s orced will know – this is when the arguments really begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour remainers back john bercow over brexit
story: An official inquiry condemned him and his regime for a hideous culture of sex harassment and intimidation going back years. Two bullying accusations, which he denies, are levelled at Bercow.In any other organisation he would already have been suspended or fired. But Labour need this supposedly impartial Speaker to help stop the ­referendum verdict being enacted and perhaps set up another vote.Bercow, incredibly, wants a NEW bullying inquiry. A People’s Probe, perhaps, aimed at securing a dferent result.Labour’s hypocrisy is off the chart. title: brexit deal latest there may britain could stay tied to eu another year
story: Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels last night, the PM told them she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest,  months longer than No’s current transition plan.And that would include continuing free movement of all migrants, as well as the UK having to fork out another £bn into EU coffers in fees, while having no say in any Brussels decision making.The PMs high stakes play runs the risk of infuriating hardline Brexiteers who have long opposed keeping any ties to the EU beyond Brexit day on March , let alone for almost three more years.An EU official told reporters after Mrs Mays speech: She said the UK would be ready to consider the extension of the transition period.European Parliament President Antonio Tajani, who was also invited to listen to the PM’s  minute address, confirmed her signicant move.MEPs’ boss Mr Tajani said of the summit discussion: “Both sides mentioned the idea of an extension of the transition period as one possibility which is on the table and would have to be looked into.Downing Street had earlier insisted a transition extension was “not something we are calling for”.But Mrs May herself refused a point blank chance to rule it out, ducking a direct question from ITV News on her arrival in Brussels.Mrs May left the dinner after her half-hour speech, as the other  leaders enjoyed a meal of turbot cooked in beer.But Tory MPs lined up to slap down her suggestions just minutes later.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries said thatshe was suggesting a transition extension, she should step aside - and slammed the billions that could now be spent paying more to the EU.Its time to stand aside and let someone who can negotiate get on with it and deliver. I fully support DD [David Davis] as interim leader, she added.Andrea Jenkyns agreed, telling ITVs Peston: It’s ludicrous that it’s two years on and we haven’t got a deal. Extending [the transition] just kicks it into the long grass.And John Redwood said her plans would be unacceptable, saying: I dont think MPs would vote for it.Nigel Farage added: This is another betrayal of Brexit... I dont think she can survive this.He speculated it could mean British taxpayers having to pay an extra £BILLION to the EU.But Tory Deputy Chairman James Cleverly played down the suggestion of extending the transition period - pointing out that it was only a proposal from the EU.He refused to rule it out, but said Michel Barnier put forward a proposal which our Prime Minister and negotiating team will think about.The PM also held separate meetings with Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker, Emmanuel Macron and Irish PM Leo Varadkar today.But despite the high level talks, EU leaders said tonight that despite intensive negotiations there had not been enough progress between negotiators to come to a deal.They said that a November summit was off the cards for now, but stood ready to hold a December one in the hope that a deal could be sealed there instead.No had already given up any hope of forging a orce deal at the summit before it even started.The Brexiteer called the EU “a gravy train soaking us dry”.It had been billed as the “moment of truth” for an agreement before last weekend’s big row.Mrs May also asked the leaders to show “courage” to help her break the impasse.And despite talks stalling over Ireland yet again when a deal brokered by bureaucrats collapsed on Sunday, she also insisted an agreement was possible and appealed for them to come up with “creative” ways to help her.Mrs May told the leaders: We have shown we can do dficult deals together constructively. I remain confident of a good outcome.The last stage will need courage, trust and leadership on both sides.After she delivered the pitch, Mrs May was then asked to leave the summit room so her fellow national could deliberate over her words with dinner.The PM ed to the UK Representative to the EU’s official residence in Brussels for dinner alone with her aides.Under Mr Barnier’s proposal to extend the transition period, Mrs May must inagree to keep the whole of the UK in an indefinite customs union as a backstop to keep the Irish border opentrade talks to deliver another solution fail.But Mrs May has already ruled that out, and Cabinet ministers have demanded a legally binding mechanism to ensure any backstop is only temporary.Ireland’s Taoiseach Leo Varadkar gave his backing to the extension as one way of breaking the Irish border deadlock, but only under Mr Barnier’s conditions.Mr Varadkar said: Any extension to the transition period couldnt be a substitute for the backstop.We would still need to have that, but perhaps it would allow people to have greater confidence that it would never need to be invoked.”Some EU leaders began to express open doubts that Mrs May will ever be able to strike a deal with them because of Tory party turmoil over Brexit.Lithuanian president Dalia Grybauskaitė: We do not know what they want, they do not know themselves what they really want - thats the problem.“If you have on the other side of the table a negotiator who has no strong mandate, its very dficult to negotiate.”Ms Grybauskaitė, dubbed her country’s own ‘Iron Lady’ because of her black belt in karate, added: “The Brits must decide finally want they want, and rally behind the Prime Minister and not split, not battling, to have a joint opinion and joint stance.”But other EU leaders were more optimistic, including France’s Emmanuel Macron who said the EU would “find deals” to secure an orderly Brexit.The French president last night emerged as a key figure of support for Mrs May to break the Ireland impasse, having lead the way in torpedoing her trade deal proposals at a summit in Salzburg last month.Mr Macron was one of four EU leaders that Mrs May held one-to-one meetings with in Brussels ahead of the summit’s start.Another pivotal player, Germany’s Angela Merkel, was also supportive, saying: “We want good relations with Britain.“We would have been happythe exit deal was ready. Instead, we are  percent there.But I will tackle the issues in good spirit and try everything to find an agreement.”It also emerged tonight that Mrs May has invited  chief executives to take part in a conference call on Friday to brief them on the status of Brexit negotiations.The invitations, which were sent out today, are part of efforts by Downing Street to build a closer relationship with business.And in a blow to the PM, French officials today published a paper stating that in a No Deal scenario, British visitors to France would in principle need a visa to enter the country, and would be considered illegal immigrantsthey failed to apply for one.The document also revealed that French ministers are planning to implement new border checks the day after Brexitthe two sides fail to agree a deal.Its the first time a major European country has publicly announced plans for how it would cope with a No Deal outcome.On a crucial day in the Brexit process:At the start of todays summit, some leaders expressed optimism about the chances of a deal - Dutch PM Mark Rutte said: Im cautiously optimistic that over the coming weeks Michel Barnier and the negotiating team in the UK will come to conclusions.Angela Merkel claimed a deal was  per cent done, adding: I’m approaching this with the spirit of always trying to do everything to find an agreement.But Lithuanias president Dalia Grybauskaite said the UK had yet to agree its own negotiating position.She said Britain needs to rally behind the Prime Minister all together and not split - to have a joint opinion and joint stance.And chief negotiator Michel Barnier added: We are not there yet. Brexit must be orderly for everyone and for all the issues, including on the island of Ireland.So we need time, we need much more time, and we will continue to work in the next weeks calmly and patiently.Belgiums Charles Michel said: We are concerned because we see it is dficult in the British Parliament to have the same views on the future of the relationship between the EU and UK.The EU meeting which started today was previously earmarked as the moment when leaders would sign off an a withdrawal agreement.But talks broke down over the weekend after the EU insisted on a border backstop which could carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Mrs May told a Cabinet meeting yesterday that she wont accept any deal which which breaks up the Union - or which keeps Britain tied to the EU customs union permanently.And speaking to MPs in the Commons today, the PM said: We continue to work for a good deal with the European Union - a deal that delivers on the Brexit vote but also a deal that protects jobs and livelihoods and crucially that protects the precious Union of the United Kingdom.We will not accept any proposals which would effectively break up the United Kingdom.She accused Jeremy Corbyn of preparing to betray voters by laying the ground for a second referendum on Brexit.Mrs May also rejected the Labour leaders claim that her Chequers proposals are dead after she failed to mention them by name in two recent speeches.Today Michael Gove suggested that a deal might not be signed until December - just three months before we officially quit the EU.He told a Commons committee: It might be the case - we’ve seen how European negotiations work - that progress is made at October council, progress is made at the November council, and it is even as late as the December council before a deal is done.Obviously, everyone wants the deal to be done earlier.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed one of the biggest threats to Brexit is Tory MPs like Boris Johnson who refuse to back Mrs Mays approach.He told the Daily Mail: Boris is a backbencher so he is free to say exactly as he thinks.But what I would say to Boris is be careful because there is a real danger thatall of us Conservative MPs do not stand behind the Prime Minister at a moment like this, the danger is that Brexit will be derailed altogether.I am sure that this is last thing Boris wants.The pro-EU veterans made a direct appeal to politicians across the EU, asking them to back calls for a second referendum.They wrote a joint opinion piece which appeared today in a number of European newspapers.The trio said: Our domestic debate is far from over and, even at this late hour, many of us are continuing to make the case that the British public need to make the final decision once we are in possession of all the relevant facts.So we ask our European partners to be ready to give us the space and time,necessary, to make such a final decision.They accused Brexiteers of being cynical pessimists who want to get a flimsy exit deal that they would later tear up in order to impose deregulation and tax cuts.The ex-PM and two former deputies have been blasted by Brexit-backing MPs who say they are undermining Britains negotiating position.

story: These cells, which convert sound vibrations into electrical signals, are killed off by age or noise damage — and mammals cannot regenerate them.But a US team was able to renew them after lab-testing a theory that birds’ “growth factors” could be manipula­ted to give a simi­lar result in mammals.Prof Patricia White, of Rochester University, said the re­search could lead to “restoration of hearing”.She said: Our research is focused on finding a way switch the pathway temporarily, in order to promote both regeneration of hair cells and their integration with nerve cells, both of which are critical for hearing.The process of repairing hearing is a complex problem and requires a series of cellular events.You have to regenerate sensory hair cells and these cells have toproperly and connect with the necessary network of neurons.This research demonstrates a signalling pathway that can be activated by dferent methods and could represent a new approach to cochlear regeneration and, ultimately, restoration of hearing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: emmanuel macron angela merkel brexit summit theresa may
story: The French and German leaders were spotted enjoying a pint in the centre of Brussels after dinner with other EU bosses.The pair were joined by Belgian PM Charles Michel and Luxembourgs Xavier Bettel for drinks in the citys main square.It came after all EU leaders enjoyed a dinner of mushrooms and turbot at the European Council summit.Before the meal, Mrs May gave a -minute speech setting out her proposals for a Brexit deal - then left to dine alone.She was hoping to secure agreement for a special Brexit summit to take place next month where a deal could finally be signed off.But Eurocrats told her there are no plans for such a meeting because the two sides havent made enough progress in ongoing talks.A spokesman said: “The EU leaders stand ready to convene a European Council,and when reports that decisive progress has been made.“For now, EU is not planning to organize an extraordinary summit on Brexit in November.”The news could push the deal back to December - setting up a crunch Commons vote just days before Christmas.The EU leaders refused to discuss Brexit as they drank in Brussels last night.Asked about the issue, Mrs Merkel quipped: Please, it’s a wonderful evening... let’s not spoil it.And quizzed about the encounter this morning, Mr Bettel said: It was very good. We had french fries and a beer, we are in Brussels so it was very nice.The PM today risked fury from her own MPs by confirming she is considering a new plan to extend the post-Brexit transition period.EU leaders have proposed a longer transition, leaving Britain tied to the bloc until the end of , as a way of solving the Irish border issue.Mrs May said this morning: A further idea that has emerged, and it is an idea at this stage, is to create an option to extend the implementation period for a matter of months.

title: brexit deal latest theresa may says plan to keep britain tied to eu is only a matter of months as tory vultures circle
story: The PM has faced a furious backlash from her own MPs worried about a further delay to Brexit.The plan could cost the UK as much as £billion as we continue to contribute to the Brussels budget, according to top Tories.Arriving for the second day of the European Council summit, Mrs May claimed the proposal would only be an emergency measure to avoid a hard border in Ireland.She told reporters: A further idea that has emerged, and it is an idea at this stage, is to create an option to extend the implementation period for a matter of months, and it would only be for a matter of months.The point is that this is not expected to be used because we are working to ensure that we have that future relationship in place by the end of December .In those circumstances there would be no need for any proposal of this sort and Im clear that I expect the transition period to end at the end of December .During the transition period, Britain will continue to be treated asits a member of the EU even though we are officially leaving in March next year.That will mean paying in to the EU budget and remaining part of the single market and customs union - meaning continued free movement of people, and a ban on cutting new trade deals around the world.Yesterday Eurocrats asked Mrs Mayshe would consider extending the planned transition until December , a year longer than previously pencilled in.The idea is to give both sides longer to thresh out a hi-tech solution to the Irish border issue which would take away the need for checks on the island of Ireland or in the Irish Sea.But after the PM signalled she may be open to the idea, Tory MPs hit out at the desperate ploy - and even called for her to quit.Leading moderate Nick Boles, who backed Remain in the  referendum, warned Mrs May she is shedding support from her party.He told the BBC: Im afraid she is losing the confidence now of colleagues of all shades of opinion, people who have been supportive of her throughout this process.They are close to despair at the state of this negotiation because there is a fear that both the Government and the European Union are trying to run out the clock, that they are trying to leave this so late that they can credibly say there is no alternative but a no-deal Brexit and most people agree that would be chaos.That is not an acceptable way for a leader of a government to behave.He claimed another year of transition would cost the Treasury nearly £billion in additional payments to Brussels.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries called on the PM to quit rather than make more concessions to Brussels.She tweeted: If Theresa May is asking for a longer transition period, she is stalling. It’s time to stand aside and let someone who can negotiate get on with it and deliver.Another senior Tory told The Sun: There are now billion reasons why Mrs May should go - this is not delivering the referendum in any way shape or form.Think what that £billion could be spent on at home, police, schools, more doctors. Its a shambles.And Remainers also mocked Mrs May - Labours Gareth Thomas from the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign said: The Prime Minister can give herself as much Brextra time as required but its not going to work.The Northern Ireland border issues are signicant and the stark reality is that buying a few months or even another year, albeit welcome, will not solve the problem in itself.The PMs de facto deputy David Lidington said a longer transition was in the mix but refused to confirm how much an extension would cost Britain.He said the price tag would have to be teased out during further talks with Brussels.In other Brexit developments today:Arriving for the second day of the European Council summit, Luxembourgs PM Xavier Bettel said time was running out for a Brexit deal and claimed Mrs May is under huge pressure.He said: On March , its game over. March  is the last day when the UK is a member of the EU so we have to have a deal before.We know Theresa May is in a tricky situation because she has got huge pressure in the UK and at Westminster.Ex-ministers including Boris Johnson, David Davis and Iain Duncan Smith last night wrote to the PM calling on her to ditch her Chequers proposals or risk a humiliating surrender to Brussels.They said: We urge you to make clear that you will not bind the UK into the purgatory of perpetual membership of the EUs customs union, whether by a backstop or any other route.Talk of either a UK or a Northern Irish backstop is inimical to our status as a sovereign nation state.

title: wetherspoons customer burger art ketchup
story: Molly Napier-Doyle, , created the works of art on the distinctive Spoons floral plates using ketchup, mayonnaise, brown sauce and mustard.She created a version of the Mona Lisa called Mayo LisaThe talented teen had been eating burgers and drinking cocktails with friends in their local Wetherspoons on Holloway Road when she decided to start playing with the leftovers on a whim last week.Swapping her paintbrush for a wet paper straw and using pictures on her phone as a reference, Molly claims she painted the ironic art to give her pals and the waiters a laugh.Giving Da Vinci a run for his money, fine arts student Molly mixed leftover mayonnaise and mustard together for the Mona Lisas skin.The portrait of Mollys idol Frida Kahlo was garnished using leftover limes, tomatoes and lettuce leaves as substitutes for the Mexican artists iconic hair flowers and earrings.Molly created the works of art using a wet straw in WetherspoonsThe Mayo Lisa and Frida Ketchup drew smiles from the server too as she cleared away their plates - and Molly claims the chefs were so impressed by her art they even sent her a fruit yoyo to say thanks.Molly, from Bolton, but now living in London, said: It was just a whim - I was having fun with my friends in a Wetherspoons and thought it would be funny for the waiters to see that when they came to collect the plates.Frida Kahlo is a face Im very familiar with because I paint her a lot and I thought that would be a fun one for me.The Mona Lisa is such an icon I thought it would be funnyit were re-created out of sauce.Molly,  is an art student from BoltonMy friends were just laughing and supporting it.One of the servers who took it away thought it was cool as well.She was saying the kitchen staff were taking photos of it.I think it was a dferent experience painting in food. It was quite dficult and it wasnt something Id planned.Molly, who has been a student at the Royal Drawing School for nearly ten years and now studies at City and Islington College, claims she loved putting her foodie twist on classic artists - and joked about doing something more condi-mental next time.She said: Frida Kahlo inspires me a lot. Shes just great. I like her style.Ive painted the Mona Lisa before. I know shes an icon in the world of art but I think shes actually got quite an easy face to paint.A previous drawing of the Mona Lisa created by MollyI guess I could specialise in food art in the future. Art is such a vast thing and I dont know what I want to do to.Im getting a lot of good feedback from this so its definitely opening up an opportunity.Eddie Gershon, a spokesman for Wetherspoon, said: Both pieces of art are superb and definitely one offs. title: china launch artificial moon chengdu sichuan
story: The project is set to be completed in  and, according to People’s Daily, the articial moon is “designed to complement the moon at night”.The fake moon’s glow is predicted to light up an area with a diameter of -km with its precise illumination range being controlled within a few dozen metres, making it eight times as bright as the real moon.The articial moon’s brightness will be enough to entirely replace street lights.The project was introduced to the public by Wu Chunfeng, chairman of Chengdu Aerospace Science and Technology Microelectronics System Research Institute Co., Ltd.Wu made the announcement at a national mass innovation and entrepreneurship activity held in Chengdu on October .Wu explained that the testing of the illumination satellite started years ago, and now the technology has finally matured.The project has sparked concern from the public, as many began to worry that the lights reflected from space could affect the daily routines of certain animals.Kang Weimin, director of the Institute of Optics, School of Aerospace, Harbin Institute of Technology, assured that the light of the satellite is similar to a dusk-like glow, so it should not affect animals’ routines.The cost of the project has not yet been announced.A similar project was planned by Russian researchers in , as plans were made to use orbiting mirrors to light up cities in Siberia, hoping it would be a cheaper alternative to electric lighting.The scheme developed by Russia used a device called Znamya . It was equipped with a -metre mirror to illuminate a three-mile wide patch of land.During its first orbit the craft was destroyed following a collision in space. The scheme was abandoned, reported the .

title: couple photobombed captain titanic belfast
story: Cheryl and Luke Arkless, both , were on a trip to Belfast in Northern Ireland when they decided to visit the Robinsons pub – a bar famed for its memorabilia from the doomed ship.But after the Devon couple snapped a romantic shot together they were horried to spot a ghostly face right behind them – which they believe bears a great resemblance to the ship’s captain, Edward John Smith.Cake maker Cheryl, a mum-of-two, said: “My mother in law took three photos of my husband and I, all of them within seconds.“It was a bit cold at our backs, but we didn’t see or feel anyone behind us.“It was only when we flew back to England and when I was looking at the photos that I noticed something blurry.“I called my husband and he said it was probably a person walking behind us very fast.“But the thing is, everything around us is crystal clear apart from that blur.“I was very sceptical at first but now I really think it looks like a man.“There is a strong Titanic background in the bar, and the more you look at the more he resembles the captain.“On the right hand side behind us a band was playing, so he looks ashe is watching the band.”Cheryl and Luke visited Belfast with his parents over the summer and had met some friends for a few drinks on July , when the picture was taken.The second bar they visited was the Robinsons, a pub famous for its Titanic vibe as it features items recovered from the wreckage including letters and postcards written on board, first and second class china used on all White Star Line vessels and a Philomena doll.The image has just been released for the first time after Cheryl enlisted the help of ghost-hunting group Paranormal Investigations UK, who analysed the picture and ran a series of tests to confirm it was genuine.Cheryl added: “I was intrigued, I simply wanted some answers.“When I got the report back from Paranormal Investigations UK I was freaked out, as they said the picture was  per cent unexplained.“I was left with more questions than answers.“I phoned Robinsons to tell them what happened, but they said nothing like it had been reported before.“My children were fascinated – I showed them the photo and explained to them that whatever is in that photo is not meant to be there and then we all watched Titanic together- they didn’t know what it was or that it was a real ship.“After watching the film, my daughter Yasmin pointed out the face in the picture saying ‘look mum, it’s the Captain’.“I literally got goosebumps, because I had not told them anything about it looking like the captain.“I was excited and creeped out at the same time – she is adamant is the captain in the picture.

title: toddler traps hand escalator handrail china
story: The incident happened on October , as the young child was visiting a shopping centre with her family in Linshui county in Chinas south-western Sichuan province.CCTV images show her and an older boy descending the same escalator side by side while holding on to the handrail.But as she reaches the bottom, she keeps her hand on the handrail and follows the moving belt all the way under the escalator until it reaches the inlet.The fingers on her right hand then appear to become stuck in the mechanism, causing the escalator’s fail-safe to kick in, stopping the moving steps.An adult behind the girl quickly rushes to her aid, but the woman - possibly her mother - was unable to free the child’s hand.Footage shows dozens of shoppers gathered around the escalator as the girl is helped by technicians and members of the fire service.She is believed to have been freed in the end after several minutes, but her exact condition is unclear.

title: parents children military photos calendar officers association
story: A touching goodbye cuddle between an eight-year-old girl and her RAF stepmum features in a new collection of photographs celebrating military heroes and their kids.Proud Lillie Rose Messenger can be seen wrapping her arms around Corporal Ursula Beetham, , as she sets off on a tour with the  Air Mobility Wing.The goodbye hug took place at RAF Brize Norton and was submitted to charity Little Troopers for their annual calendar by Lillies mum Louise Marshall, .Proud Louise, from Carterton, Oxon, said: The picture was taken at Brize Norton Terminal before one of Ursulas numerous trips away with  Air Mobility Wing.We feel privileged to be chosen as a winner and hopefully help raise a lot of money for a worthwhile cause as it is service children that sometimes get forgotten about.The calendar also features -day-old Evelyn Rose Pearson curled up in her Army dads beret.Shes now four-months-old and her dad Warrant Officer Jamie Pearson, , serves with the st Battalion the Yorkshire Regiment.Mum Amy, , from Warminster, Wilts., said: The photo was taken in our married quarters in Warminster.Were so happy to be a winner. Im really proud of my husband and its lovely to show my family how unique it is to be an army family.Another photo shows Millie McSeveney-Liddell, four, leaping into dad Jordans arms, welcoming him home after six months deployment.Little Millie brought a bag of sweets to her dad, a private in the  Scots.Mum Linzie McSeveney-Liddell, , said: Millie was very happy.Jordan had been away for six months, which is the longest her daddy has ever been away, so she was so excited to welcome him home and give him the sweeties she picked for him.Decembers page shows Louis Darwell, just  days old, getting a kiss from dad, Lieutenant warfare officer RN Joseph Darwell, , currently on HMS Clyde.Mum Rachel Darwell, , said: We wanted to capture as many precious moments with Louis as we endured a dficult pregnancy and he was our rainbow child after suffering seven miscarriages.This picture was taken when Louis was  days old, and his daddy had been training at Dartmouth and had just Passed Out in July .I was due to give birth and on the day of the Passing Out I started to go into early labour.We nearly had little Louis at the Royal Naval college, but he arrived a week later.The calendar has been created by Little Troopers - a charity which supports service families - so they can help more than , children.Little Troopers aims to help maintain the family bond between children and parents serving in the British Armed Forces, regular or reserve.Louise Fetigan, founder and operations manager said: This is our charitys seventh calendar and once again our military community have sent us some beautul pictures that truly capture the heart-breaking reality of our familys lives.The last cuddle before a long deployment or that welcome home hug where you just want to hold them forever is so special and we have some of those moments and lots more in next years calendar.This year the charity was sponsored by the Officers Association, so all the money raised from the sales can go into the charitys work.

title: boy allergic reaction dinosaur birthday cake stoke
story: Mum Ali Carstens bought the custom-made cake for her son Deysels third birthday party.But after blowing out his three candles and taking a bite of the cake in front of his friends, Deysel suffered a terrying allergic reaction and was taken to AE.Ali said she specically requested for no egg be put in the dino-cake she ordered from Sophie Amelie Creative Cakes in Aylesbury, Bucks.She says the company confirmed they could cater for his requirements but Deysel, who is allergic to egg, began to vomit at his birthday party in front of shocked children and their parents.His lips rapidly blistered and his face swelled, and he needed emergency treatment at Stoke Mandeville Hospital, said Ali.She added: Not only were we terried, but the kids at the party must have been traumatised.The whole room was so shocked when Deysel began to be sick and his face was swelling up.We rushed him straight away to AE - we were absolutely terried.The worst thing about allergic reactions is you dont know how big the reaction will be nor where it will stop.We were terried his airwaves would close up and he would go into anaphylactic shock.Luckily the staff at Stoke Mandeville AE were very helpful.He was given anti-histamines and steroids to try to control the reaction.Someone from the cake company came to Stoke Mandeville to apologise immediately.Ali is now in contact with the local trading standards team and says they are set to launch an investigation.She added: Deysel is now afraid to eat.Were finding it really hard to get him to eat his dinner for fear of another reaction.Its heart-breaking but its also bad for the kids who saw it, who must be traumatised.Sophie Amelie Creative Cakes said in a statement I had no idea how the eggs could end up in an egg free cake, but unfortunately thinking of it once I learned about the reaction I realised it could be traces of egg white powder that was used for other orders that day.The customer was notied of it immediately, along with apologiesthat was the cause.My page states clearly that all sorts of allergens are handled in my kitchen and therefore traces of those might be found in all the foods prepared here,that was the cause of Deysels reaction.

title: terrifying monster baby dolls with gory scars and frightening fangs brought to life by horror movie fanatic
story: The thought of having a demonic half-monster baby sounds more like a night terror than a lestyle choice.But for artist Julia Hamill, the fanfare over her sordid creations has turned her passion project into a full-time job.Founder of Okie Babies, Julia Hamill from Muskogee, Oklahoma, creates reborn monster baby dolls which merge hyper-realistic new-born detailing with freakish features such as fangs, scars and fur.Made primarily from silicone, Julia adds real animal teeth into the dolls’ mouths to provide them with an even spookier edge.But the most toe-curling characteristic comes from the eyes which follow their owners around the room.Selling from anywhere between £to £the one-of-a-kind dolls take up to  hours to complete with each fibre of hair meticulously placed, and each vein precisely drawn by hand.Detailing her journey from niche creative hobbyist to professional artist to Travis Hoefle of The Wizard of Odd TV, Julia said: “I like to bring dead things back to le.“What’s so confusing about my dolls is they look really evil or look asthey could hurt you, but they’re actually babies. They’re really cute.“I’ve always had a thing for horror movies, so I wanted to take my version of what those things would look like in my head and put it on these dolls.“All of my babies are one-of-a-kind – I never make an exact replica and I’m constantly creating new versions.”Julia continued: “I really like adding pieces of bone and teeth – whether it be human or animal – into my dolls. I just love turning things that have died back into something beautul again.“Okie babies has changed my le, I now no longer work a - and can be around my family a lot more.”

title: tracey britten pregnant uk oldest mum quadruplets
story: The Sun revealed how Tracey Britten, , is expecting three girls, including identical twins, and a boy after spending £, on IVF treatment in Cyprus.Now, against all odds, Tracey - already a gran of eight - will reach  weeks tomorrow in her pregnancy, despite doctors saying there was no way shed make the milestone.Doctors said the babies could come anytime now but have booked her in for a c-section at the start of November. But she said her birth is so unusual, the babies will have to be split up immediately after birth, with two sent to a dferent hospital.She said its because the hospital near her home only has TWO specialist incubators - and shell need four.Shes also revealed how she has been given steroids to boost the growth of the little ones lungs, because they will arrive so early.Tracey, of London, who has been ordered to remain on bed rest, said: I had my scan last week and they have booked me in for a c-section in around two or three weeks time.The consultant said he doesnt think Ill get to that stage, but then they all said I wouldnt get to  weeks.Im on weekly scans now.Im taking each day as it comes. Its really at the point where every day counts, and the longer they can stay in the better chance they have of being healthy when they are born.But they have said that the babies wont all get to stay in the same hospital.Two will stay where they are born, but two will be taken to another hospital - hopefully quite nearby.He said its because they only have two specialist incubators in my hospital. I said cant they bring them to me and he laughed.Its more complicated than that, and he said they only have two, so two of the babies will be split off and taken in a special ambulance with an incubator as soon as they are born.Im going to be here, there any everywhere, but of course what will be, will be.In my last scan last week and all is very well, but the doctor said put your feet up as much as you can. Im supposed to be on bed rest.But the babies are all fine and healthy. I had two steroid injections at  weeks.Thats because I could go into labour at any time and it gives their lungs a boost.The doctor said to me that they are all ok, but he said he cant make any promises when they are born.But thats the case for any baby - evenyou are having just one.Tracey said she has stuck by her decision to not buy too much baby gear before the babies arrive.But she has ordered four baby seats to take the little ones home from hospital.She said: They said I would never get to  weeks, and here I am at . It really is a miracle.So far, so good. Im trying to just take each day as it comes.Tracey had three children - now ,  and  - with her first husband, but they split in  and she met now husband in , marrying in .She had preliminary tests done via her GP in the UK and signed up with a private clinic in Cyprus called Kolan British IVF Center, now called Team Miracle.She started a course of hormone injections at home and flew out in April - telling friends and family she was going on holiday.She controversially had four embryos implanted in one go and against all the odds they all developed into successful pregnancies.The former drug counsellor paid for the treatment using inheritance left to her by her mum Pauline Smith who died in .She said her mother always wanted twins in the family, and feels the babies are a gt from her.Tracey said she doesnt care what her critics have to say, and has longed for another child since an abortion she regrets having  years ago.Doctors suggested she reduce the number of babies she is carrying through selective abortion, but after consulting forums, discussingShes now having scans every week and plans to raise the children in her rented three-bed home, with husband Stephen.

title: pregnant meghan markle prince harry royal tour melbourne
story: Meghan-mania hit the Victorian capital as the royal couple continued on their tour around Australia - but it was Harry that left one fan in tears with excitement as she scored a hug from the -year-old prince.India Brown, , was overwhelmed when Harry spotted her sign saying: “Been here since am, loved you since I was .The teen burst into tears as the prince gave her a hug, said to have told her: You are going to get me in trouble.Its another busy day for the expectant parents, who have so far seen their namesake koalas in Sydney and got a taste of rural le in Dubbo during their -day whirlwind tour of Australia.And the couple seemed delighted as they got the chance to visit an Australian beach to learn about its sustainability program and chat with lesavers about their work.The pair were seen laughing with the brightly dressed workers, with one leguard later saying: We asked themthey were going to go for a swim today but we all decided it was a bit too chilly.Maybe another time when theyre down here.Meghan was seen chuckling at the suggestion, telling the group: Maybe not today.The royal couples reluctance could be put down to the overcast Melbourne day, with the pair both wearing jackets as they hit the beach.Meghan arrived in Melbourne wearing a navy dress by Aussie designer Dion Lee and a Martin Grant trench coat while Harry was pictured in a dark jacket.The outfit showed off her growing pregnancy bump after the couple announced they were expecting their first child just days ago.The new royal remained sensible for the beach visit - swapping into flat eco-friendly shoes made from recycled water bottles by Rothys.Prince Harry and his we had caught the tram to the beach where they were peppered with questions from local students - which even includedthey had chosen a baby name yet.But Meghan remained tight-lipped on any possibilities, saying: Weve been given a long list of names from everyone, were going to sit down and have a look at them.The couple arrived late to their first engagement of the day after reportedly getting stuck in traffic, but their delayed arrival did not damper their excited welcome.The duchess was even presented with a tiara by an Albert Park Primary school student, with locals have waited from as early as am to catch a glimpse of the royals.The duke picked out Annie from the crowd after seeing her holding a bunch of flowers and toy tiara.Are they for her , he asked, gesturing towards his pregnant we.Meghan then came over, took the gts and said: Oh my goodness, thank you. Those are amazing.Harry also got a smile at the school when he was given the opportunity to name the pet snail, and suggested Speedy.As the couple left, one little boy told Harry: You remind me of my uncle.The duke replied: Is that a good thing  Is it because Ive got a ginger beard The expectant parents stopped to play with five-and-a-half-month-old Harriet Bonaddido and chatted with her mum Jessica during their walkabout.The -year-old said: As soon as I introduced my daughter to Harry, he said thats a great name.Maybe they will choose it for their own child, which would be fun.Meghan was right behind him and was playfully tickling her toes and said how sweet it was that Id brought her out today.Other signs including Worth the detention and Fresh Prince with red hair were held aloft to the party, who made their way through the Royal Botanic Gardens to Government House.Meghan was also keen to try out Australian Rules, taking the footy and giving it a punt to one of the women during a display from Victorias This Girl Can empowerment campaign.After tossing the ball, she laughed, saying: Im not sure I did it right!Jerril Rechter, chief executive of VicHealth, who showed Meghan around the event, said: She did pass an AFL football. She did a handball. Thats a pretty incredible thing for anybody to do.She had not seen an AFL football before Howard, the governors husband, explained to her what it was like - the weight of it is a little bit dferent, and that you handball it, you dont pass it.The duchess is said to have told kids she didnt have much spare time but she enjoyed relaxing and watching TV shows.But the former Suits star reportedly hesitated when asked what her favourite show was - saying: Theres heaps, I cant think of one.The Duke and Duchess are partway through a -day tour, during which they will see the Invictus Games and travel to New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga.Earlier today Meghan was caught on camera jumping in fright at a backfiring toy F car.The Duchess of Sussex was racing the models at a demonstration in Melbourne, when a loud bang made her flinch in fear.After landing in Melbourne for day three they were met by a crowd nearing , and abandoned their strict scheduling to meet royal fans for  minutes.Gts, including toys, flags and flowers, were given to the parents-to-be as a group began to sing Stand By Me, the gospel song performed at the royal wedding in May.One of the larger presents of the day came from Courtney Pistone, , who held a large teddy over the barriers and handed it to Meghan for the unborn baby.She said: I gave it to her for the nursery.I thought it would be suitable because we didnt knowit was a boy or a girl and both boys and girls like bears.The couple also got a taste of Australia as chargrilled kangaroo was on the menu for lunch as they visited restaurant Charcoal Lane.The restaurant, in the hip Fitzroy area of the city, served up an entree of mushroom and quinoa nest and chargrilled kangaroo and main courses of wild boar, saffron risotto and barramundi.It was prepared by chefs who were trained by the Mission Australia programme, which assists young indigenous Australians into employment.October They were greeted with hugs and flowers as they arrived in Dubbo just days after announcing they were expecting their first child in spring next year.Meghan is said to have told royal fans she was running on adrenaline as the couple fit in  engagements in  days.The Duke of Sussex said he and his we could not think of a better place to announce the upcoming baby than Australia.

title: esa refund am i owed
story: NewsESA refund: Am I owed thousands after DWP benefits blunder affects , The mistake means that Employment and Support Allowance claimants lost up to £, each over seven yearsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe number of claimants has soared - and so has the bill for back payments "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTens of thousands of Britons have been left wonderingtheyre in line for a refund after a benefits blunder by the Department of Work and Pensions. It is estimated that , sick and disabled people will be paid about pound.bn in benefits they were wrongly denied. The mistake means that Employment and Support Allowanceclaimants lost up to pound, each over seven years. The number falling victim has soared from , to , since errors were identied last year - and so has the bill for estimated back payments, ministers have admitted.  The bill was initially pegged at poundm but the cost of the bungle will hit pound.bn by  as a result of ongoing higher payments. Underpayments resulted from the DWPs failure to assess whether they qualied for income-related ESA rather than just the less generous contribution-based ESA. In July, Secretary of State for Work and Pensions Esther McVey, facing a legal challenge, caved in to calls to refund people all the way back to . The DWP had already accepted that it wrongly underpaid disabled people switching from Incapacity Benefit to ESA and had begun the process of reimbursing claims after October .  The blunder emerged when officials found some people transferring to ESA from incapacity benefit were put on the wrong system for assessing their new payments. The bill for back payments also rose due to evidence gathered by a -strong DWP team that is still reviewing , cases. Am I owed back payments Those affected are largely people who converted from incapacity benefit, an old-style benefit, to the contributory version of ESA. The DWP has said it will be contacting those who are owed money and there is no need for claimants to contact the department themselves. However, critics say payments have been sluggish and some have contacted the DWP directly in a bid to speed up their case. A spokesperson for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.”  When will I be paid  The new estimates show poundm arrears will be paid to , through to April . Another poundm will then be paid to an estimated , in the   financial year. How much am I owed  A small number of Employment and Support Allowance claimants lost up to pound, each over seven years. About , entitled to the severe disability premium were estimated to be owed around pound, each. The arrears payments, which mainly cover a period between  and , are expected to average pound, per person.  How will I be paid Recipients can expect to receive back-dated payments within  weeks of being contacted by the DWP. Payments will come through the same way their benefits are paid - usually directly into their bank account. What about claimants who have died  Yes -your relative died while waiting for payment, you should be entitled to claim their benefits. DWP Minister Sarah Newton told the House of Commons: Tragically, people who’ve died who would have benefited from this additional payment, their families are being contacted, we are trying to find their families, so they can have that money. Will that money be paid back with interest  Its not clear. Ms Newton dodged this question when asked directly in the House of Commons on Thursday.  Who is affected  Some . million people were transferred from older incapacity benefits to ESA between  and . An estimated , recipients are due arrears, up from the initial estimate of ,. What are critics saying  Rob Holland, co-chair of the Disability Benefits Consortium, which represents  charities and campaign groups, said: “Close to half of those in poverty are disabled or live with a disabled family member. “In addition to making sure disabled people are paid, the Government must reverse cuts built into Universal Credit.” Labours Marsha de Cordova, shadow minister for disabled people, said recipients have been short-changed and denied the social security they were entitled to. She said: This mess is another example of how the Conservatives have created a hostile environment for sick and disabled people. The Government must ensure that disabled people who have been so unfairly treated are properly compensated. A Government that forces disabled people into debt and even makes some destitute is a disgrace.

title: liam fox pulls out saudi
story: NewsLiam Fox pulls out of Saudi investment summit after outcry over Jamal Khashoggi disappearanceThe Tory International Trade Secretary has pulled out of the summit in RiyadhShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsInternational Trade Secretary Liam Fox "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLiam Fox has pulled out of a major investment summit in Saudi Arabia, following outcry over the disappearance and reported murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. title: paul routledge labour must put
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Labour must put national interest first and help Theresa MayMirror columnist explains how his family served in the British Army - and he hasnt forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itselfShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionThe EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailListen to me, just for a moment. I speak for many more of my generation than you might think. I was born in , when my country was fighting for its le against Nazi Germany and it was not clear that we would win. My father Harry was in the RAF in the Middle East. My Uncle Bob was a tail gunner in Lancasters over occupied Europe.My Uncle Jack, a Guardsman, had been invalided off the beaches at Dunkirk. Even my youthful Auntie Barbara was in the Auxiliary Territorial Service. This was total war – the Americans fighting and dying with us, for our freedom. At home it was all wartime austerity. Food and clothes were rationed. Travel was suspended. I ask you to remember because so many have either forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itself. Remember the Blitz on London and Hull. Remember Sheffield, Coventry, Plymouth, Liverpool, Bath and York. Remember, Auschwitz, Treblinka, and the other death camps where millions of Jews were exterminated. Remember El Alamein, Tobruk, Normandy and all the battlegrounds where people gave their lives to free us from Hitler.Remember all these things and consider thoughtfully what must be done to ensure that these horrors never happen again.  The EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees. It is not perfect, made up of all the flaws of the people of an old, culturally and racially erse continent that historically has more often been at war than at peace. But it is nothing short of a miracle that they found the wisdom to get together in their common interest. I do not care what Theresa May brings back from Brussels, just so long as it keeps us good friends and partners with the rest of Europe. I want the peace that my father’s generation fought for to be preserved in perpetuity, for my children, and generations to come. So, when Mrs May s with her Brexit package, I look to the politicians – including those Labour MPs who have the country’s real interests at heart – to support her in the hour of the nation’s need. At this critical time it is more important to vote for a new relationship with Europe than to blindly follow the elusive dream of Jeremy Corbyn in No. The crunch is coming and it will reveal the true patriots. Because of the war I did not see my father until I was three years old. But I was lucky. At least Sgt Routledge came home. So many others didn’t.

story: NewsTory MP Paul Beresford left utterly baffled by Scottish accent in hopeless House of Commons exchangeWeve all been there, right  Well, maybe not for a Scottish person. And definitely not in the chamber of the UK ParlaimentShareCommentsByJenner McKiernanDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video sir-paul-beresford-really-cant-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWeve all been there, right  Someone has a thick accent and, slightly embarrassed, we ask them to repeat themselves. But we probably havent all done it twice. With someone who is... from Scotland. And we definitely havent all done it in the House of Commons. That was the predicament faced today by former minister Sir Paul Beresford. Conservative Sir Paul, who holds dual New Zealand and British citizenship, said: Im sorry, it must be something to do with my antipodean background. Could you please repeat the question because I didnt follow it  Amused Glaswegian David Linden, an SNP MP, asked for a second time how the Commons was improving access for disabled people.There was laughter and a comment of oh wow from the SNP benches. Sir Paul still struggled and asked again for Mr Linden to repeat it more slowly and in antipodean English. Deputy Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle, who has a robust Lancashire accent, intervened with faint irony: I think the answer might be helpedhe can reply in writing.  Mr Linden then resorted to sign language to confirm he would write it down. He is not the first SNP MP to have dficulties making himself understood. Last year, SNP MP Alan Brown revealed ministers have so much trouble understanding his thick Ayrshire accent that he rarely receives direct answers to his questions when he speaks in the Commons chamber. Reporters at Hansard, the official verbatim report of Parliament, struggle with the same problem. They pass notes to the SNP backbencher asking him to write out what he said whenever he rises to speak.

story: NewsGrand Designs host Kevin McClouds advice on where you should NEVER buy a homeThe veteran TV presenter has issued this stern warning to prospective house buyers looking in these at-risk locationsShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT NewsKevin McCloud has warned prospective buyers looking in these areas "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTV presenter Kevin McCloud has developed a well-earned reputation for being an expert on all housing related matters. story: NewsHow teacher accused of pupil plane sex beat tragedy before lurid blackmail claims destroyed glittering careerEleanor Wilson, , was once a high-flying student and highly-regarded teacher but now her career is in tattersShareByMirror:,  OCT NewsA jury failed to reach a verdict in Eleanor Wilsons trial "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEleanor Wilson was once a star student and highly regarded teacher quickly rising through the ranks. But during a week-long trial at Bristol Crown Court Miss Wilson was accused of developing an inappropriate relationship with the boy on a school trip to Swaziland in southern Africa. She learned yesterday she will not face a retrial over allegations she had sex with a pupil in an plane toilet.The court heard the  teacher, , lured the teenager into a toilet on-board a flight back to London in the summer of  and slept with him. But the jury failed to reach a verdict and the Crown Prosecution Service announced on Wednesday it would not pursue a retrial.  Despite having no criminal stain on her character, her career in teaching appears to be all but over, with the evidence showing an inappropriate relationship with a teenage pupil she had messaged more than  times. Its a far cry from her early years which pointed towards a brilliant career ahead - she was someone regarded as a fine and talented teacher by parents and colleagues. According to the Daily Mail, her early le was marked by tragedy when her father Barry Wood suffered serious injuries in a motorbike accident just a day before she turned four. He died days after his daughters birthday in . She was raised by her mum, the newspaper reports, in a terraced house in the former mill community of Silsden, West Yorkshire. When her mother married Stuart Wilson, Ellie took his surname.  A friend from Miss Wilsons years at South Craven School in Cross Hills told the Mail: School work was something Ellie found extremely easy, but she wasn’t remotely practical. She stuck out wherever she went with her height and blonde hair, but at the same time she was quite goofy and gawky. She was obsessed with science and won an Ogden Trust prize for being top of her year in physics before gaining six A*s, three As and a B in her GCSEs in . They were reportedly the second best results in her year and Ellie was spoken about in glowing terms in the local newspaper. Her mother said at the time:I expected good results, but not this good. I am very proud. Miss Wilson went on to study five A-levels — two more than most of her peers.  It was aged  she had her first brush with the law. She appeared in court after knocking down a teaching assistant at the school in her car in June  while looking for a parking space, according to local news reports. The woman suffered a fractured knee, broken finger and badly grazed her face.Miss Wilson pleaded guilty to driving without due care and attention. She said it had been raining hard at the time and she had not seen the woman. Skipton magistrates imposed six penalty points on her licence and fined her pound. She was also ordered to pay pound costs and a pound victim surcharge. Despite this mark on her record she took a degree in experimental physics at the University of York, graduating with first class honours in . She then qualied as a teacher. Within a year at a secondary school in Bristol she had been promoted to head of Key Stage Four.  The headteacher at the school - which cannot be named for legal reasons - said: She was an excellent teacher — incredibly hard working. She taught engaging lessons and she was popular among colleagues, students and parents. Unusually, I had parents emailing me to thank her for the work she’d done with their son or daughter. But in the summer of  her blooming career took a dramatic turn. Evidence heard during her trial suggested that Miss Wilson was obsessed with the boy she was accusing of sleeping with. It emerged during the trial, for example, that she had exchanged some  texts, calls and multimedia messages with the pupil, who had her saved in his phone under the moniker Smurfette. Most of these were deleted before the police could retrieve them. Having sex with the boy in the plane toilet was not the only illicit behaviour alleged by the prosecution. After the trip to Swaziland, Miss Wilson was alleged to have had sexual contact with the boy on three further occasions — once in his bedroom after lunch at Nando’s and again on day trips the pair went on to Tintern Abbey in Monmouthshire and Ashton Court Estate, a country park in Bristol. Miss Wilson admitted in court she met the pupil on these occasions - and that she had texted him almost daily over that summer.  But she said the meetings were innocent and that her relationship with Andrew Hall was in trouble, with the couple rarely having sex. The prosecution alleged she told the boy she was pregnant and her plans to have an abortion. Prosecutor Virginia Cornwall showed jurors a long note the boy had written on his phone about the termination. Did you want me to have no choice to kill my own child  it read. Why are you trying to f***ing kill me  You took my happiness, you took my dream, you took my confidence  Those times on the grass in the summer laughing... kissing, touching me, telling me you love me. Soon the rumour mill at the school went into overdrive with the pupils parents and staff quickly becoming involved as his story came out: that he and Miss Wilson had joined the Mile High Club on the A Airbus on the flight back to the UK. Miss Wilson soon found herself being blackmailed.  In February  she received an email which read: I know about you and [the boy]. Wouldn’t want that coming out, would we. I have a deal, replyyou’re interested. Yours, anonymous. The pupil attached a picture of his genitals. But instead of reporting it to the headteacher, she replied over the course of two days. But the pressure got too much for her. She broke down and told the teacher of being blackmailed. The messages were traced to a pupil, who was removed from the school. They triggered the inquiry which led to Wilson being dismissed in May . She was banned from teaching by a tribunal in July . In her police interview she said the boys story sounded like some weird porn film.  There were two versions of what happened on that British Airways flight from Johannasburg to London. The first was given by the pupil who said Miss Wilson had kissed him and touched him intimately before luring him into the toilet, where they had had drunken sex. This sexual encounter, the pupil alleged, resulted in Miss Wilson falling pregnant and subsequently having a termination. The second was given by Miss Wilson, who said that she had watched Disney’s Cinderella when she wasn’t attending to a number of pupils suffering from food poisoning - and that nothing inappropriate happened. It was pointed out during the trial her  height would have made it very dficult to have sex within a confined aircraft cubicle. Her lace-up hiking boots would also have hindered her. Last week her week-long court case ended in a mistrial with a hung jury unable to decideshe was guilty or not. Every day at Bristol Crown Court she walked in, hand in hand, with her new boyfriend -year-old Josh Hawkins.

story: NewsKleenex bins its Mansize tissues brand after increasing complaints about sexismThe company said it is changing the name of the tissues to "Kleenex Extra Large" following feedback from customers.ShareCommentsByJosie Clarke:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe tissues will no longer be branded Mansize "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKleenex is scrapping its Mansize tissues branding after consumers complained that it is sexist. The company said it is changing the name of the tissues to Kleenex Extra Large following feedback from customers. Kleenex For Men first launched in  with the claim that they would stay strong when wet. However consumers have tweeted Kleenex to ask them why its products still use the term Mansize, saying the world is changing and that it is .In a statement to the Daily, a spokesman for parent company Kimberly-Clark said the firm is registering a consistent increase of complaints on gender concern.He added: Kimberly-Clark in no way suggests that being both soft and strong is an exclusively masculine trait, nor do we believe that the Mansize branding suggests or endorses gender inequality. Nevertheless, as we remain committed to developing the best possible products for our consumers and take any feedback extremely seriously, we decided to renovate our current product and update the product subbrand as Kleenex Extra Large.  The move by Kimberly-Clark comes as Waitrose said it will be changing the name of its Gentlemans Smoked Chicken Caesar Roll because of consumer complaints that it is sexist.
